The company has a great 401K plan and very flexible on work at home and when you need time off.  The company is really forward thinking and trying hard to be thought leader in wellness.
cons: The mission translates down to the individual departments, but each department is in their own world and do not know what the other teams do.  For new hires, there is very little department training (a lot of Humana training) and they just throw you in to begin on your own, but your manager and team mates are so busy with their own work, they don't have time to help much.  The dream of Humana does not translate fully to individual teams.  There is a lot of individual responsibility where each team member works on their own issues while on the same team, others are doing something completely different.

review_title: At Humana, you learn a lot, work a lot, but not paid a lot.
pros: A lot of smart, intelligent people work at Humana, specifically the corporate office. Humana provides ample benefits if you don't get sick often, offers tuition reimbursement, and is an overall stable work environment. Also, Mike McCallister is a great CEO and he will be missed when he retires.
cons: Pay is much lower than industry averages. In order to get big pay increases, you must move around the company to do so. Even then, HR caps the increase (was told no one gets more than 20%), so if you start with the company as I did and they low ball you, you are pretty much going to be under paid at every position. Actually now that I am writing this, it seems most of the problems I have had with this company have boiled down to HR and it's terrible management.

pros: A large company with a lot of room to grow and advance. They have great work life balance a,s offer work from home in most areas and roles below executive roles.
cons: Silos rule at Humana. Different departments may as well be different businesses, with each working more for their own self interest then the greater good for the company. It's also a "clicque" culture where it does not matter how good you are, you will not advance if you are not hanging with the right crowd. Most times, the hiring manager will have decided who's getting a role before they even post it as open, in the interview process is just a formality to keep compliant with HR. The company also struggles with corporate goals and values trickling down to individual departments. There is a lot of talking the talk, but not walking the walk in that regard.

review_title: Humana is a professional organization that has opportunities for growth both as a company and as an employee.
pros: Future outlook of the company and Mike McCallister as the head of the board and CEO.  I believe in Mr. McCallister's vision for the future.  While some see the demise of our industry, I believe our Sr. Leadership will help us innovate and be successful in the future.
cons: Large Fortune 100 organization that can be bureaucratic at times.  The challenges can be found in holding leaders responsible for meeting results while balancing the needs of employees.  Too often, leaders see important initiatives as "optional" and that can slow down progress.

pros: I loved my job at Humana. I started at an entry level position and was promoted quickly. There is heavy training where you are given the knowledge to complete tasks thoroughly and efficiently. I loved the atmosphere in Louisville. Employees were encouraged to engage with each other. Although there is micro-managing, I excelled in each position I held. I still to this day, absolutely LOVE Humana!
cons: Unfortunately, when I relocated to Miami for the SIU position, I was involved in a car accident and took short term disability. I feel that my release from Humana was not right, I still absolutely loved working for this company. If given the chance, I would go back in a heartbeat.

review_title: Ginormous Potential and the Right Heart
pros: Solid company with clear direction for the future. The executive committee is a very respectable and talented leadership-body, that IS trying to make a difference in the world, and the workplace.
cons:
Mis-micromanaging everyone because there are loafers that actually need to be managed. I fear people are afraid to "let people go" but I believe that sends a message to them; that their incorrect behavior didn't advance them, and maybe they should change. However, if the leadership is guilty of similar behavior, then they cannot comfortably do-so.
I think leadership should be screened for their interpersonal, psychological and people-skills. I have had some very unprofessional and negative experiences. 
Multiple incidences where I was so shocked that I had to question whether or not I was in the Twilight Zone.
Also, I believe when you chain a dog; they are going to run if you let them off.

review_title: dead-wood won't float a company forever
pros: Job stability is a real plus. This work environment is very large and you can find people here that are truly dedicated to working to improve healthcare and the member experience. The environment is really entrepreneurial and new initiatives can be initiated at small levels fairly easily for a Fortune 100 company.
cons: It is a gigantic company that lacks true cohesiveness. Leadership has a tendency to be selected via seniority over talent/skills and that favors the persistent or lethargic employee therefore middle management ends up being the most ruthless and CYA-ish group which deters true thought and true innovations. Humana does not reward to its own vision. The employees that stay are mediocre at best and have a tendency to be like their middle-managers lethargic and resistant to work. The company is fragmented into deep silos even within its departments.

review_title: Could be awesome but ruined by incompetents
pros:
There is a lot of work to do for those (few) willing to do it. 
Very stable industry
cons:
Full of contractors unable to think their way to a fix (most are completely incompetent)
A lot of permanent employees who coast through their day by passing all the work to others.
No cohesive vision, lack of direct leadership until the ship run aground then its a witch hunt rather than seeking solution
No dedication to quality, only getting code out.
Culture of COYA, not of a "Thrive Together"

review_title: Direct Marketing Sales DMS Medicare Agent
job_title: Direct Marking Sales Agent in Miramar, FL
pros: Training is great a lot learning about health care industry, about Medicare products Managed Care Advantage Plans. Also, they pay for one to get License through Gold Cost Agency pay Courses and training certification. That is the big deal for someone starting health care industry. Once one gets licensed will find better opportunity else where !
cons: Stressful, No Opportunity, to move up into a Management  position, through sales Market Point Sales Department. Next is opportunity to became a  Team Leader DMS after working at  lease five years. However, one must work a lot of hours overtime 80 hours at week during Annual Enrollment period.Personal and family time sacrifices.Also anyone gets fired for any silly reason making environment for permanent and temporary employee to be afraid  losing their jobs. Pay is below the standards 15 dollars plus commission if make any !  Temporary employees get release unnoticed  at any time and you must keep watching your back at all time because someone will tell on you if any wrong doing.

review_title: Sometimes too good to be true
job_title: Right Source Specialty Pharmacy in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
-Even though we have mandatory overtime, we feel appreciated and like we are important to the team success.
- There are a lot of perks to get healthy or stay healthy. I have never been so encouraged by an employer to take care of myself.
- Supervisors are more then willing to take time to discuss issues with you. If you feel like you don't understand something, someone will help you.
- My co-workers are amazing. Everyone takes time to smile and say hi everyday. We encourage each other and can turn to each other when help is needed.
cons: - Attendance is very very strict. You can get fired for poor attendence no matter how your performance is. It is easy to ask for a day off. You can't be late all the time and you need to stay on schedule as closely as possible. Being rude to customers and poor attendance will get you fired very quickly.

job_title: Medicare Customer Service in Tampa, FL
pros: Great training program. Starting salary was great at the time I started my position in the company.  More of a family atmosphere in the company.  Managers and Supervisors and other higher ups were very accessible.  Taking calls for the Medicare side,
cons:
I wasn't a fan of the time off policies, where all vacation and sick time is rolled into one.  Part of the reason I left was due to the fact that I felt I could not advance.  There is room for advancement within the company, don't get me wrong, but certain departments would not even grant me an interview, even though I received good reviews for my work in my primary department, and other projects I were assigned to. It felt like to advance, you had to be chummy with certain people higher up.  When I did advance, the position was phased out months later.  

The health insurance benefits were ok at best overall.  High deductible health plan.  Paying out of pocket for prescriptions.

There were times where Customer Service Reps received additional duties without any additional compensation for their work.

review_title: Out of touch upper management at NSO
pros: The RE/ISE associates are fantastic to work with...each bringing a different approach to the same job.   The RE/ISE managers are good leaders when they are allowed to "manage" their teams and not on countless phone meetings or have stuff pawned off on them from top 3.     The wellness aspect of Humana is second to none!!
cons: Top directors sit in their office all day and delegate duties to their managers.    Besides counting phone calls, 99% of employees have no idea what they do all day besides micromanage the employees.   Phone call requirements are beyond outdated in a company that promotes technology based apps.....all except the NSO...gotta continue to make worthless calls to make quota.    Top 3 managers are protected by the  "Boys Club" network with upper level management in Green Bay and Louisville.  Call volumes are celebrated more than productive sales....SAD.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in West Chester, OH
pros: Healthcare is growing and Humana's stock is doing well. I like the management which I report to.
cons: In meetings I get to hear how the companies’ profits and stock are going way up but I have lost one third of my income since last year. If a raise is given at all, it will be about every 16 months instead of yearly. The raises do not keep up with inflation. In spite of becoming a more valuable employee I am actually losing money. In addition to poor wages there is pressure to contribute your personal time and money to charitable causes in the name of Humana. I support charity but not to give a company a good name at my cost and effort. I appreciate the diversity Humana embraces but they do it by creating groups. I get emails telling me that I should celebrate all these other groups of people but there is actually no group for me. I Feel their groups separate me from others.

review_title: Inconsistent, busy only 2 months out of 12
pros: Gain sales experience, good company values
cons: Way too inconsistent. One month you are on a sales campaign making your salary plus commission and the next zero commission. No explanation, no nothing. It's horrible to think what the company gets away with. Be prepared to live off only your base salary at times and be prepared to be treated like just a number. There is a reason why they hire by the hundreds. Think about it! Also the busy season is only from oct- dec. Get ready for forced copious amounts of OT & weekend work during that time and get ready to twiddle your thumbs the rest of the year. Also.. In the interview there was no mention of Outbound calling. Ha! No matter how good you are or if you make presidents club you WILL be cold calling 80 year olds and trying to pitch the plans. Good luck!

review_title: It is an okay place to work - it is such a large organization that there is a huge variation in job quality/satisfaction
pros:
Strategically, humana has made some very good decisions in building its business.  
In Louisville, it is one of the larger organizations, and salaries are pretty good relative to others in the area.  If you don't like your current role, there is plenty of opportunities to move into different teams as it is much easier to be hired internally than externally.
cons: Humana as a company of its size appears to have some dysfunction in its organization and operations.  As mentioned in the title of my review, there is incredible variation in the quality of the team within Humana.  Some teams are stuck in the stone ages of business process and IT quality.

review_title: A company trying to re-invent itself
pros: Very good ethical atmosphere, hard working, and oriented toward doing well by doing good. There is lot's of opportunity when coming up from the bottom for hard work and creativity to be rewarded. Good benefits and reasonable pay (very good for the area around Louisville). There are signs that the new President is shaking things up.
cons: The upper level management is hampered, at least in IT, by an entrenched culture which may give lip service to innovation but doesn't is too cautious to make real change. Some policies, particularly regarding the way funding get's allocated cause a highly siloed environment. There are signs of change but working there is a source of perpetual frustration.

review_title: It's not what you accomplish, but who sees it
pros:
A lot of smart, intelligent people work at Humana.
Decent health benefits, unless you get sick often or have kids.
A Centre College bachelor's degree seems to provide some sort of magical pedigree for advancement.
Mike McCallister is a brilliant CEO, Humana will miss his leadership.
cons:
Negotiate a salary with which you'll be satisifed for at least three years, because you won't even smell a raise before then.

I agree with the observation that Humana is not a Fortune 100 company, but a small Kentucky health-plan that got extraordinarily lucky to stumbling onto a federal program (Medicare Advantage in South Florida) early on, and that the place is run like a Rotary Club -- you can only advance based on personal popularity, regardless of what you've accomplished.

Calibration seems to only reward only associates in positions who have high visibility -- I've seen star employees with timid directors get passed over for raises that were rewarded to mediocre performers reporting to glad-handing dandies.

C'mon it's 2012, how come people who never get to leave their cubicles have to wear neckties?

review_title: Loved my job, until I went to a knew team
job_title: Business Analyst in De Pere, WI
pros: Great pay, PTO time, holidays off. If you seek a challenging position you most likely will get one. Most supervisors are pretty good. They really want to mentor you, give you a chance to express your thoughts and ideas.
cons: Once one supervisor is upset with you, that is it your days are numbered. You could be doing everything right, but in just a few months it will look like you have done everything wrong, and you will be let go. Even if your on a small team, and you are given 75% of the responsibility and the other 25% is divided among 2 other people.

pros: Decent Benefits (Great PTO, Agile work, 401K match, good maternity leave benefit)
cons: This company has very high expectations with little to no guidance. If you ask for any help the response you get is either "I don't know" or "I don't deal with that" so you are often left to figure it all out on your own. With that said because you are given lemons and expected to make lemonade you spend a lot of time at work to meet deadlines. This throws the work/life balance off. There is also a lack of efficiency due to low budgets to invest in automating a lot of task that takes way too long to complete manually.The culture is the typical corporate environment  A LOT of politics and favoritism which damages morale.

job_title: MarketPoint Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: It is a job with pay. 401K is generous if you can afford to fund it.
cons:
Health insurance for employees are all high deductible plans, quite unaffordable for most new hires without second household income.  

Most employees are afraid to take time off  in fear of management targeting. 

I left over a year ago and am still the target of criticism and blame on weekly conference calls (at least monthly) as the reason for low plan performance - not horrible Customer Service or plan benefits designed by computers, not people. My management acted like spoiled vindictive frat boys vs insurance professionals. 

Medicare sales teams have NO moral compass. Medicare Customer Service less than that. Employees and Members are treated like an inconvenience of doing business. 

Humana knows everything and is responsible for nothing - and yet in some markets they have the lowest rated plans others, the highest. Everything negative is blamed on exiting employees and un-informed members. Positives are the wisdom of management.

review_title: The WORSE corporate company i have ever worked
pros: The benefits are ok.. not the best considering its an insurance company, i've seen better.
cons: None of the management wanted to take escalated calls while witnessing them all laughing and joking around while employees waited to be assisted. Also, the training was TERRIBLE. I was in my position for 10 months and still had not reached my full potential because of their tactics. I dreaded going into my department truth be told. Also, front line leaders dont even know the guidelines as they have never been on the phones and cant even take escalated calls. also, if you get on one of the team leads bad side, they will go out of their way to put your position at risk... the way humana operates you would have thought the team lead was the supervisor..

pros: Good benefits,  learn a lot about medicare,  free CEUs,   great co-workers,   can WAH,    wellness focus,  volunteer time given,   Decent PTO
cons: Long hours, and lousy clinical systems.   Overly focused on quanity not quality.    They talk about work life balance but dont staff enough so nurses have to work long hours,  sometimes weekends.   Now that they changed nurses to hourly pay,  they will start to care and then start to micro manage even more.   They seem to single out nurses for micro management for whatever reason - other areas of the company arent monitored nearly as much.

review_title: Great, if your work is your life.
pros: The strategic path the company is on holds a lot of promise for future growth and continued stability. Certain areas of the company are more balanced than others, definitely reflecting the leaders and level of leadership there. As it adopts and applies its own strategy of wellbeing to its own behavior, the potential for an improved and better balanced culture may be realized.
cons: The current workload and work expectations are those of a workaholic culture where the priority is on achieving overly unrealistic deadlines at the expense of work/life balance and employee wellbeing. The leadership team at the director level is inconsistent in terms of leadership quality and ability to lead, with promotions based on insider politics and "being liked" over expertise and actual leadership.

pros: Great way to help a significant amount of people, for many there are career choices and paths to take for advancement, very good benefits, as with most jobs you can make this one as good or as bad as your actions and words earn for you
cons: It is a very big company with all the benefits of that but many of the issues also. The division you are in may be totally dysfunctional. Transfer and find that the next division runs smoothly with a minimum of political infighting. The opposite is also true. My division has weathered its bad spots but keeps coming back to smooth because of the focus on the patient.

review_title: Eight hours of no work is supposedly better than a few hours of hard work.
pros: Humana is the largest employer in the Louisville area.  If you would like to have a fairly normal schedule and move up in a large organization then Humana is a good place.  If you put in your time, you will be moved up and compensated nicely.
cons: There is very little recognition for talent.  As a talented young person, it will probably be difficult to remain at Humana for an extended period of time.  My skill level passes my compensation in every new venture, and it there is very little mobility withing each department.  In order to move up and get compensated for your ability, you must move and find another department in the company.

review_title: I like the job alot! As far as the people I work for not a whole lot.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tucson, AZ
pros: I thoroughly enjoy working with my coworkers! I've met a few new friends.
cons: 2 years ago we had some good things. This year for example, no ice cream social like the Humana employees had, nothing extra like that which would be great. Just makes us think since we are not direct Humana employees we are not appreciated. Like we are less than lower class.

job_title: Human Capital Analyst in Louisville, KY
pros: Decent flex work options. Some managers are decent.
cons: I had reviews for 2016 that were labeled "Exceptional" on both criteria. I was granted an award for service. Then they found out I had a mental illness and had to go into the hospital.  On the day I was released from the hospital, 2 business days following my award and 3 weeks following superlative evaluations, I was informed they were "accepting my resignation" when I had never offered it.  They knew they couldn't legally fire me, so they made up that I had resigned.  Sound like an ethical employer that is open to supporting employee well-being?  My position was certainly not eliminated either, as I saw it posted shortly thereafter.  If they really thought they were on firm ground for firing me, for whatever reason, they would've have done so and not claimed I'd resigned without being able to provide any proof that I had resigned. You could excel at every part of your job, but if they get a whiff of mental illness difficulties, they will find a way to make you gone.

pros: Work from home, decent benefits, excellent 401k and PTO. Teammates are generally nice. Focus on wellness and vitality program is a nice perk to earn gift cards and other rewards
cons: Inconsistent and ever changing expectations. Breakdown in communication down the line. Focus on quantity and quality with same level of measure. Consistently had software system issues that prevented ability to perform. Management would still expect same metrics despite any personal event or computer issue. The Humana At Home Dept is heading more and more into severe micromanagement of employees which makes work from home life unpleasant. Also, a lot of self selling required of the nurses and time spent handling matters outside of our job role. Unable to spend adequate time utilizing nursing knowledge to help members. Upon leaving company, supervisor neglected to terminate appropriately which caused a huge hassle with my last paycheck and dos not get paid until 4 weeks later. Team morale was continuing to deteriorate during my time there and high turnover was occurring.

pros: The company strives to adapt to changing policies and politics, and works to stay a step ahead of the competition.  Their dedication to customer service is noble.
cons: As a young, white male, I always felt like a minority in the company.  Although my many accomplishments were recognized, they were swept under the rug as "normal day-to-day work".  Due to attrition, more work kept getting piled onto already-understaffed teams, yet the company's committment to excellence left no room for mistakes.

pros: Clear history of success and profitability.  Humana has many employee associated benefit offerings and pays well.  The company also has long been a big supporter for various endeavors in Louisville.
cons:
Highly "matrixed" organizational structure that can resemble running for or working within Congress where too many people end up "lobbying" vs. producing.  This approach is designed to have many influencers and critical few "owners". 

Many organizations use this outdated matrix organizational structure and the success seems questionable.  It usually leads to more resources thrown at a problem or initiative versus a strategy and planning approach. The company has enjoyed a long run in riding the wave of the healthcare industry for the last several decades though that is coming to a tipping point, which is why the Aetna merger is in play.

There also seems to be a clear bias towards the 30 - 38 age group where most of these team members have grown up with the company, have not worked anywhere else, and have limited breadth of knowledge and experience as a result.  This can lead to becoming too ingrown.

review_title: Ok if you can hack it.
job_title: Medicare Customer Service Representative in Louisville, KY
pros: It is a large company, so the pay is decent, some people are friendly, and the training is extensive and ongoing.
cons: Most managers are only interested in what they can get, not their underlings. Parking is 1/2 mile away, take the trolley (this is in Louisville of course). If you can stand the first two years on the Medicare Customer Service floor, you will then have the opportunity to branch out to other departments, IF you reviews and quality scores are good enough.  It is a call center, big time stress levels, you will never know all the answers, you have to know where to look for them, you time is watched down to the second, every minute of every day. Since there is way too much to learn or know, wrong information is often given to customers.

review_title: Great bunch of smart, hard working, down to earth people who get the job done well.
pros: The people are great and they have a good balance between the regions and the corporate headquarters.  They have good benefits and a reasonable bonus structure.
cons:
One of the biggest "cons" is the communication environment with senior management.  They create an atmosphere where people don't want to tell them bad news.  So there are a lot of pieces of the company that hobble along and are falling apart but are portrayed to upper management as doing just fine.  

There is constant change.  They implement strategies without building the infrastructure to support it.  It has advantages of speed and creates a sense of urgency, but it is often times fairly disconcerting for the folks who have to implement the strategy.

review_title: No room for advancement in Orlando, Fl market
pros: The salary is great and they are family friendly, i.e. leave early for Dr. Appts and such. Flexible hours on holidays, overall great work-life balance.
cons: Poor health benefits considering it is an insurance company. No room for advancement locally, you'd have to be willing to relocate. Too much favoritism, it's not what you know but who you know and get along with well. If you brown nose enough and get drunk with your boss after work than you'll be golden. Too much immature behavior by employees and management. It's a shame because the company is not bad but the management in the Orlando, FL market office has a lot of growing up to do. Complaints are made, but nothing gets done; they just gossip about it and laugh behind the backs of the people who lodge concerns.

review_title: Great company as a whole; Some Directors on Power-Trip
job_title: Corporate Analyst in Mountain View, CA
pros: Great Corporate Mission. VP and higher up are actually easy to talk to and are receptive to input. They go above and beyond to help employees develop a satisfying career path.
cons:
Some Directors of some departments are on total power trip. They promote the "yes-man/woman" based on kiss-up; rather than credentials and hard work. Some departments will try to "re-invent" processes over and over again. Associates are then discriminated against for asking questions about the unnecessary re-invention of a process that currently works, then written up for questioning, and told not to worry about it that the re-invention of process creates job security of the department. Hmm, apparently didn't work too well for LGUW.

Very poor high deductible plans for employees.

pros: For the most part this is an okay place to work.  Reasonable opportunity to advance if you wish, good training resources available online and in the workplace.  Pay and benefits are fair compared to the market.
cons: Business needs take precedent over holidays, so be prepared to not have certain holidays off.  You are compensated extra for having to work though.  There can be quick changes in management and since Humana hires based on leadership potential sometimes rather then experience, you may end up with a manager that doesn't know much about how a certain department works.

review_title: Great culture, healthy place to work
pros: Great benefits, travel, plenty of time off, encouraged to have work-life balance and make healthy choices. Everyone is super positive for the most part, easy to work with and get things done.
cons: Forced to wear two hats at the same time, effectively two full time jobs with no relief and no overtime. Expected to just keep head down, be positive, and get it done. Some politics. The local tech support for our area of Humana had this guy who handled most issues I needed addressed, and he's always kind of a dead inside, curt kind of a guy. Not fun to call for help.

pros:
Saw this organization make a significant shift from payor to consumer-focused wellbeing organization. Was proud to be a part of that effort as well as seeing leadership step into the unknown. As far as the basics (pay, benefits, 401k match, etc.) one of the better companies I have worked for over my career. Pay was incredibly competitive locally, benefits included health (high deductible with HSA, Dental and Vision), 7.25% 401k match on the first 6% you contributed - a significant match. PTO was ~22-23 days and was very generous.

Also, loved the culture of 'bring your whole self to work'. It didn't matter who or what you were...we accepted all and in the areas I worked, focused on results.
cons: Growth into senior leadership levels can be limited and the performance review process or ability to be recognized was lacking.

review_title: Too big and out of control - Caveat Emptor!
pros: You can fly under the radar for years and no one cares. The number of inept people impacting the health of others is a majority of the 45,000 employee base. Your are so compartmentalized you do not know the end result of your actions. Mantra of "Perfect Service" is touted by all and practiced by few. Very security conscious and protect themselves from every legal angle to a fault. Micromgmt is an art form level on low end of the career ladder. Largest datamining operation in the world.
cons: "Perfect Service" is not. Don't get between the revenue and management with an idea requiring money. Mgmt is focused on sales and their bonuses, not the people stepped on or over along the way. CEO is a bean counter without regard to the human condition. Another Humana business about to crash and burn; milked the nursing homes; then the hospitals; now health insurance; what's next?

review_title: Not worth putting your heart into but it might be worth the paycheck for you.
pros: The kitchen in the cooperate tower has great healthy food at a great price. The gym memberships are also a great value if you use them. It's a decent job if you don't value your life or what you do for a living.
cons:
It seemed to me that most people working at Humana spent 80% of their day covering their rear end and 20% working. It was amazing the lengths people went to in order to not be responsible for anything. And as such, if you needed help from any other department at Humana, it was like pulling teeth to get it done. A couple times while I was there I asked another team to do something and heard back a year and a half later when it started showing bad on their automated reports.
And a word to the wize... they will try to screw you out of some money in your offer letter. Check the math, it's always wrong.

pros: They do offer great training, and encourage you to take advantage of their training on the job resources.
cons: Nothing stays the same long enough to utilize the great training they give you. or offer through the on the job resources.   They hire Managers who don't have the education they require of the staff they hire. The salaries are much lower than ANY other comparable companies and the benefits - really! what benefits this is a healthcare company and the employees have a $5000.00 deductible. All I have to say is DON'T GET SICK!

pros: Work from home, good salary, benefits are standard.  Training is good. The company spends a lot of time selecting you, training you, promote well being and balance.
cons: Then....they throw you to the wolves. Metrics. Have increased 3 times since I started 7 mths ago. All you can think about is making numbers that have no reflection on the quality of what you do. You are micro managed and constAntly told what the organization expects. It is grueling and there is no balance for well being time. It's like working on an assembly line of phone numbers. One after the other after the other. Give us a break. Let us be the professionals you hired. Stop with all the numbers.

job_title: In-home RN Care Manager in Rogers, AR
pros: Great PTO accrual, 3 weeks/year to start.  They match 401k contributions at 125%.  Many positions offer work at home opportunities.  Company is fun to work for,  supervisors are supportive and fair, individual uniqueness is encouraged.  Company offers many social groups and acitvities to join.  Very accepting of all employees regardless of age, race, LGBT status, ethnicity, etc.   The company is very friendly and welcoming to employees.
cons: Workloads can sometimes be heavy but balance out in the long run.  Company has history of laying people off unexpectedly due to financial projections for upcoming business year.  Employees can get frustrated at lack of transparency from upper management during times of change.  Not fun to live in constant fear of being suddenly laid off.  Recently, there seems to be a new wave of layoffs every 3-4 months.  Many employees express anxiety about their long-term careers with Humana.

pros: I work for a great director, and am challenged to think and be innovative at work.  As an organization, I feel that there is a commitment to growing the business, and a desire to be better integrated integrated across the organization.  We are moving slowly in that direction.
cons:
A lot of our operational infrastructure and work processes on the commercial sales side are antiquated and disconnected.  It can be operationally challenging for commercial accounts to do business with us.  Brokers are required to have different work methodologies for small group and midmarket accounts.  As technology as a whole races ahead with Web 2.0, the operational gap in sales becomes more and more obvious to brokers and customers.  

We have so many products and options on the commercial side, making it difficult to sell.

review_title: A Company That Truly Cares about the Health of America
pros: Humana is a nice place to work, with constant and steady values that do make the employee feel important and secure. Humana definitely pushes the health responsibility of the individual, making sure that people take responsibility for their lifestyle habits.
cons: Overall pay and compensation could be better. Benefits for Employees is not that great considering it is a healthcare company. There is an inconsistentcy in the policies around the company specifically with managing the workforce, telecommuting acceptance, and knowledge dispersal.

pros: Humana encourages employee health with programs such as biometrics, humana vitality, wow dollars...good work from home option, 401K is good, health benefits and college reimbursement starts on day 1.
cons: Salary leaves much to be desired, raises are based on budget.... you might not ever get one! PTO starts at 3 weeks but takes 5 years to increase.  Quick turn around time... good employees are not lasting... they don't put emphasis on staff retention! Insurance premiums are awful and let's not discuss the deductible!!!

review_title: Acceptable place to work, could be more fair by recognizing hard work instead of brown-noses.
pros: Flexible schedule, vacation up to 3 weeks given immediately within 6 months. Benefits ok, could be better. The best of the benefits is time off is decent.
cons: Too much politics, senior management unaware of the games people play. Fairness towards employees being hired/fired is unethical and abused. Recognition should be based on performance from your immediate managers point of view, and not the other several supervisor/managers that don't even know what you do all year; a.k.a "calibration"(Ridiculous concept). Way too much time is spent on analyzing, discussing, and politcally deciding who gets the allotted raise increases, which is based on how much butt they kissed through the year and not how they performed and what they achieved as an individual.

review_title: Humana works people like slaves and then wonders why there are problems when people wear out.
pros: Financially strong company, some very good leaderships but there is no on going training for Leadership.  Promotion and raises are based on the buddy system.  Company continues to make record profits and yet it is not shared with Associates or Management fairly.
cons: Like working in a sweat shop, never enough resources to do your job. No annual performance reviews and get past over if you are not hanging out with the in crowd.  Most Directors are incompetant and do not develop their Managers.   Benefits and pay are bad, once you are hired raises are only given every other year and then if you get one it is from 2 to 3 %.

review_title: Sometimes good, sometimes not so good
job_title: Insurance Agent All 50 States in Tampa, FL
pros: The pros of working at Humana is the pay. I was a Telesales agent for insurance such as Medicare, individual dental/vision.  If the people in management like you you'll have more opportunity to make money but if they don't you could get lousy assignments like Outbound calling.
cons: You don't always get the commission you earned.  Money gets lost and you have to request an audit of your sales. And even then no one gets back to you.  You get ignored and you know you were underpaid.  The management is secretive and dishonest about commissions and how money gets lost. Upper management knows more than they'll reveal..They are loyal to one another & $$$.

pros:
-Great co-workers and synergy amongst team
-Lots of knowledge shared amongst teams
-Direct manager gives flexibility to manage work the way I see fit and has a positive attitude
-Pay has been reduced in last few years but still comparable to other inside sales roles
cons:
Most challenges or frustrations in this role come from above my leader. Directors and vp in the NSO tend to micromanage and dictate through office walls without ever getting on the floor. They have a true "do as I say not as I do" philosophy that is hard to swallow when you bust your back and get chastised over any praise. 

Other challenges is minimal training or communication on changes or processes. 


Too many meetings.

pros: Excellent employee culture focused on well-being. Engaging environment. Powerful and inspiring company mission.
cons: The compensation structure, like many large companies, is punishing to those who work their way up from the bottom. Your pay is based on the first role you had with the company. They give you small performance-based increases every 12 to 18 months. Even if you are promoted to another level, you will rarely receive more than a 10% increase. After five years with the company and three promotions, the only way to bring my compensation to a fair level would be to leave the company and come back. Doesn't seem like a good way to retain top talent.

review_title: This department is extremely chaotic and management is the worst I've ever seen!
job_title: Order Entry in West Chester, OH
pros: they offer 3 weeks vacation for the first year
cons:
*management openly shows favoritism
*if you question management's ethics, you will be fired
*management doesn't know from one day to another what is going on, what your schedule will be or how to do ANYTHING!
*high deductible insurance (mine was $1600 and that was the lowest option)
*if management likes you, you can sit and talk for hours, while getting paid and make all the others do the work
*if management likes you, you will get a great schedule and time off whenever you need it
*it doesn't matter to management if your numbers are the highest, most efficient and accurate.

review_title: Don't pick a job. Pick a Boss. Your first boss is the biggest factor in career success
pros: Humana is a good company, if you are able to find yourself in right team.  On plus side - It looks good on your resume and they have 1.25% contribution to 401k (only after you work for 2 yrs).  Typical big company with disconnected departments and its horrible to make even small thing happen.
cons: Humana is divided into number of disconnected teams and each team has there own rules and regulations.  IT Managers will make or break a rule based on there convenience and openly favors  favoritism.  Humana encourage you to report such things to there ethics helpline, but it is just a joke.  Overall my experience was not good with humana.  Culture at humana was so toxic that I finally decided to say good bye.  For big company like humana, you can get lost easily and that is reason it is important to choose your first boss carefully to have career success.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Green Bay, WI
pros: Benefits really weren’t bad. High deductible but cheap premiums. Decent HSA contributions and health incentive programs. Great PTO. Was able to work from home but on the flip side this created a huge disconnect amongst teammates.
cons: Management is incompetent in some departments. Don’t understand what their employees do on a day to day basis and ship your job functions overseas just to save a buck while quality goes down the drain. Not supportive of employees- when an angry customer wants a supervisor, expect to be yelled at and sweared at for an hour with no assistance from management. Supervisors do not take supervisor calls and can’t help when you need help. When you try to move up through the company you cant even get an interview internally if you come from the department that is perceived to be totally incompetent thanks to poor leadership.

review_title: Truly an amazing company that actually cares about it's people
job_title: Human Resources Project Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: I've never worked for a company that has cared more for my own personal development.  I've been given opportuntiies and exposure all the way up to the CEO level, and I'm just a project manager with Humana.  I'm sure experiences differ based on what department you are in within in the company, but I couldn't be happier.  To give you an example:  Twice  in the past two years, Humana has given all FT associates not on a bonus plan a $1,000 check (in which they paid the taxes on, so you actually got 1,000 cash!)  I love this company!
cons: The culture itself can be a bit oldfashioned.  The dress code is super professional in the corporate building in downtown louisville, and most employees are not very tech savy.

review_title: No upward mobility in your career
pros: Telecommuting (work-at-home) option in some departments.  Flexibility and adequate work-life balance, depending on your supervisor.
cons: No room for advancement, hence why I left in order to move into management at a different organization.  In some departments, you report to your equal, who reports to another equal.  So in essence, you have to leapfrog 2 equals just to get to a management position.  Lots of red-tape in its processes.  As an associate, you are just a number and will never really get heard or make a difference.  Humana considers that everyone is replaceable, so when that "replaceable" person leaves, all his/her projects are thrown out of whack.  They're also always looking for ways to shed employees to save money.  If you think you're on your way out, chances are you probably are.  Pay attention to the writing on the wall.

pros:
Some work from home opportunities. 
You get to understand more of how insurance is handled and processed. 
Pay is okay, higher pay in other big companies in the surrounding area.
cons:
Management is completely disconnected from associates. 
I worked a few times where I didn't get breaks and/or lunches. Which is illegal. 
Absolutely no consideration for associates work/life balance. I worked part time and would NEVER consider working full-time as there is mandatory overtime almost every week which extends to Saturday sometimes. 
Benefits are almost laughable, they should be embarrassed considering they are an insurance company. 
After I resigned, I never heard from my boss again. No exit interview, no wrap up, didn't even get escorted out to drop my badge off. 
Watch your check carefully, I was shorted almost $100.00 from my last check with no explanation and no way to access anything online.

pros: The company is fine, they offer alot of benefits and really care about employees well being. The Dual Eligible Outreach department is just disorganized and are all about numbers and not the associates.
cons: The insurance is horrible!!! God forbids you become hospitalized the bill that you're left with is ridiculous. The pay is not competitive at all, new comers are getting paid then senior associates which is not encouraging at all, there is no room for growth. Micro-managing is at an all time high. Unnecessary changes to metrics after bonus incentive implemented in order to not earn it.  The level of disconnection between upper management, to associates is ridiculous. A very simple job has turned into a dreading nightmare. Its like you're in prison the minute you log in.

pros: Some hard techs- good extra benefits (tution reimbursement, on site gym and cafe
cons: Extra long hours- mandatory overtime, gives us pto but hardly allowed to use it. Favoritism is defiantly in place. Management does not understand how mentally exhausting it can be on the phones all day getting yelled at then be talked down to about your metrics. And when you do a great job for months/ years you still don't get assigned additional off the phone work. New hires who do not have nearly as much background in pharmaceuticals nor are even certified and started out at a much higher pay rate. When you go to upper management about issues about you're concerns you are generally given a bs answer then everything is forgotten. When u are given an off the phone task the race card is played and given to another person of different race.  Not ALL departments are this risky. Member services is a big dept who often portrays this.

review_title: They don't live up to their own mission statement
job_title: Health Care Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: Working from home, good PTO and retirement plan.
cons: I feel like I was lied to from day one. I firmly believe in the company goals, but they make it impossible to produce. Continous change to process and policy, numbers over customer satisfaction, different answers to the same question. This should be a pleasurable job assisting members, but the workload is unmanageable,  and members with customer service issues take up more time than we have. Every day there are more unreasonable expectations. No input about how you are doing, but constant threats about "being held accountable" for any errors. I never mind being held accountable for my work. Here, what was right last week is wrong this week. All the work - life balance talk is a lie. If you take a day off you just get more and more behind. Unreasonable roster size, and constant pressure makes this the most stressful job I have ever had.

review_title: I work at Care Plus which is owned by Humana
job_title: Customer Care Representative in Doral, FL
pros: Pay Is decent as for Miami standard, unlimited over time , work at your own space, learn a lot of skills within the healthcare world,
cons: No room for growth, very clique , if you are not within the popular groups no growth, upper management does not show sign of appreciate toon, they treat you like robots, a huge turn around with employees due to poor management , no sense of community , no xmas party or at least a appreciation for your work at the end of the year just a thank you email , they have open positions and hire. People already knowing who they want no doversirty Cubans rule  this place 90% Cuban, sad

review_title: Limited opportunity for career growth if you do not live in Louisville and do not want a "market" position
pros: This company appears to really care about the health and well being of associates.  There is an enterprise wide sense of oneness.  Voluminous learning opportunities.
cons: While they are willing to teach you via online courses, there is a disconnect in the hiring process.  If you do not have specific experience, you are not considered for roles.  As a market associate the opportunity to learn these specific skills are limited.  It appears that no one is willing to put the time into training anyone.  The availability of "enterprise" roles are almost always required to be located in Louisville or MN--not WAH opportunities.  Again, limiting opportunities for career growth.

pros: Employee engagement was very high in this company for a while. Pay is competitive. Not exposed to sick patients every day as in retail pharmacy. Front Line Leaders go to bat for their employees as much as they are able to. (think red tape)
cons: Professional judgement only allowed if it matches that of the higher ups. Lots of system issues which can lead to errors and pharmacists get charged with the errors instead of correcting the system. Customer service representatives aren't familiar with the laws and guidelines the pharmacists must follow so give out incorrect information frequently to patients and prescribers. Metrics-expected rates rise while the number of errors allowed in a given time period remains the same adversely affecting patient safety.

job_title: Personal Health Coach (PHC) in Cleveland, OH
pros: Great opportunity to work from home. The member's really appreciate the calls that look after them and assist them in keeping up with their benefits that nornally a flyer or letter does not have the impact a human kind voice does.
cons:
Numbers, numbers, numbers is what is stressed --- There are weeks that member's do not pick up their phones. They have appointments, family and are social and they say they get to many calls. 
Moving up can be difficult -yes they do look at how active you are with other activities but when meeting metrics takes it all out of you - you just want to sign out at the end of the day and be with your family.

job_title: Retail Resolution Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: Work at home, Traveling for the company is amazing, health incentives, educational programs and flex scheduling.
cons: Management, room for advancement, promotion is sometimes based on "Who you know", if you're not a favorite of you management it's hard to be promoted.

pros: Work-at-home opportunity and fairly good benefits including 8 hours of paid volunteer time and one paid hour a week (on top of regular breaks) to use as you like for well-being activities.
cons: No transparency about pay. Job categories do not have established pay ranges, at least none that are shared with the employees. You don't know if you are in the bottom quartile or at the top of their range. They resist discussion. Also other supervisors in the dept. who have not worked with you can override the performance rating of your own supervisor who knows you best, in what they call calibration sessions. Raises have been very low or non-existent for several years. They have published something to the effect that their intent is to pay at or below average; they won't be a higher paying employer.   ...... but you get what you pay for.

review_title: RN Clinical Advisor Telecommute Miramar, Fl
job_title: RN Clinical Advisor Tdlecommute in Miramar, FL
pros: Working from home avoids the daily traffic and you can walk from bed to your office, great self health management program (Humana Vitality), PTO is fair.
cons: Salary is not competitive. Management will change policies and procedures almost daily. Tight metrics. Constant audits on work done and phone calls. Constant threats. If audits not met write ups and/or discharge is possible. Stress is high making all nurses unhappy. No raises if community volunteer hours are done, if the employee is negative in meetings and if metrics are not met. Have to visit doctors offices miles away once a month. Nurses do not last too long. High turn over of employees.

job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: There is nothing positive to say about this company
cons: The leadership (Supervisors and Front Line Leaders) is a huge JOKE!!! The FLL's get to do whatever they want without being checked for their behavior. Some of the Supervisors and the FLL's are friends so it won't do any good to report them because absolutely nothing will happen to them. The HR is a bigger JOKE as well...no need to go to them either because nothing will happen. Some of the FLL's have no Integrity at all--they will lie for each other as if this is some type of secret society to cover their own unprofessional behavior. They do not know what personal life/work balance is and if you have a family or any type of life, it means absolutely nothing to those people. The Tempe site is a huge melting pot where anything goes, at least with leadership.

pros: Flexible schedules, work-at-home opportunities, 40-hr workweeks, innovative health care products and wellness programs, decent benefits package when compared to other health care employers, especially hospitals
cons: Constant monitoring of telephone  conversations, micromanagement by front line leaders, low-level assignments after years of employment, lack of growth opportunity for work-at-home employees, repetitive tasks assigned to employees with bachelor's degrees or higher, a culture of secrecy regarding corporate strategy and departmental initiatives; bait-and-switch tactics with regard to hiring practices (Humana will hire you for a specific job--for which you will reject other opportunities--then after you are committed and on board for a few months, Humana will change your position and responsibilities and even move you to another department or simply add duties to the job you agreed to)

review_title: Flexibility, Caring managers/co-workers -- if you get the right one(s)
job_title: Senior Actuarial Analyst in Louisville, KY
pros: Flexibility to work remotely when needed, very active in trying to help you pass your exams, very dedicated to giving you study time.
cons: employee healthcare is only good if you're single, healthy, and want to stockpile cash into an HSA -- that's just not my situation..., there are some terrible managers as well, thankfully I don't work for them :)  rotation program is great if this is your first job in actuarial field, otherwise I feel it is dangerous as you could wind up with a bad manager and it will change your life for the worse.

review_title: Best job I've ever had no question!
pros: The work-at- home experience Humana has provided has allowed great family/work balance.  My coach and team are always happy to help.  The pay is amazing!  I , personally,  really love talking with the Mbr's and the challenge the job poses to better myself.. there's not a boring day. All workdays tend to move very quickly and you then turn your computer off, and go into the other room to your family..
cons: I can't really think of many at all.  There are changes very often that you must adapt your work to,  but that's with any job.  And you must obtain license in every state where Humana is offered, which is challenging to fit into the work schedule.. but it will be worth it once accomplished.  I honestly have nothing bad to say.

pros: My department has a great team mentality and I feel comfortable being able to talk to our management team with feedback on the department. I feel that they try to utilize my strengths which makes me more motivated to come to work and do a good job. Humana is trying to make a difference in the insurance industry and is a cutting-edge health and wellness company.
cons: Change is so slow. Many processes are still in the 2004 mentality before the time of huge growth. Communication between management and analyst can be very limited (i have experiences with this when working with management in other departments.) Job culture and experience can vary greatly from a customer service role to a corporate role and a market location v louisville.

review_title: My experience at Humana was rewarding and educational and supported by a strong camaraderie with my peers and supervisor
pros:
Working with people who care.
Opportunity to help others.
Strong community assistance.
Excellent pay and benefits.
Excellent growth potential.
Embraces diversity.
Encourages healthy work and home life.
Innovative and explores opportunities to expand into new product development.
Seeks continuous improvement activities.
cons:
Complex processes that can create challenges to be effective for customers.
Some of the Leadership do not get on the level of employees to truly understand challenges.

review_title: This company is not exceptional in any way.
pros: The hourly pay was good.
cons: Insurance benefits was horrible, considering this is an insurance company. If you have a problem with a co-worker for instance, the clinic manager will try to resolve it.  If that doesn't work, then it goes to the regional manager.  If that doesn't work (and chances are it won't because they are all "friends") then it is "supposed to go to the Human Resource Dept.  My suspicion is it never gets to where it's supposed to go, it just kind of gets swept under the rug until you just give up.

job_title: Human Resources Recruiter in Louisville, KY
pros: Great atmosphere.  Very professional and positive.  I was given the resources and tools needed to do my job.  My req load was average and I didn't feel overwhelmed.  My only complaint was that leadership does not recognize you as an individual unless you are a "favorite".  If you don't get "in" with the right people, you will not get a promotion no matter how hard you work.  I needed to move on in order to move up.  Unfortunately.
cons: My only complaint was that leadership does not recognize you as an individual unless you are a "favorite".  If you don't get "in" with the right people, you will not get a promotion no matter how hard you work.  I needed to move on in order to move up.  Unfortunately.

job_title: MarketPoint Sales Representative in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good benefits, depending on market good products,  strength of large Corp backing you, good investment in technology for the sales force
cons: Classic case of left hand not knowing what right hand is doing within corporate structure.  Had regional VP describe as " Fire , ready Aim",  can have lots of busy work,  company tends to manage thru reports versus actual field interviews or evaluations.  Commonly known among field sales that best way to keep job was to flood upper levels with reports so they could in turn flood their supervisors so management can continue cycle of meaningless paperwork

review_title: Company could use oversight in hiring practices, communications with HR
pros: The company has good Medicare advantage plans and meets the pharmacy needs of it's members. Working as a pharmacist I felt like I could really make a difference helping a provider or a patient.  I had the tools I needed to make a difference.
cons: Managment hasn't stayed on top of a toxic manager that has not performed. Talking to HR4U has done nothing to resolve issues. Communication with various departments feels like the right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing. Be very careful of getting involved in an organization that doesn't value you or your expertise and the manager acts by demeaning and flaunting power plays.

review_title: Humana makes up for lack of employee freedoms by providing good benefits and salary.
pros: Great benefits, good time away from work, and good compensation.  Humana provides a variety of different programs that employees can enroll in throughout the year to improve their health and learn about ways of changing their lifestyles to live healthier.  Not only are these programs offered but participation pays, literally.  The money that you earn from these programs must be used on health or fitness related goods or services.  Employees can earn up to three weeks vacation over a year and get ten sick days plus two personal days.  There is a good amount of work-life balance available for employees.
cons: It's hard to initiate any type of change in the company despite how necessary or obvious it is unless you are part of senior management.

pros: Humana cares about giving the managers training and really cares for the well-being of their associates. If you are willing to learn, you can learn a lot.
cons: All leaders are required to take leadership training courses and apply the knowledge. This seems to stop at the director level. It is frustrating having to deal with directors' petty ego problems amongst each other. I watched several sabatoge work done by another director's team, just to prove they were right. The only people that really care about associate engagement are the Process managers and Managers. The directors and higher just care about numbers on a piece of paper.

pros: Work from home, a great promise at the beginning with no follow-through. You got to work in your pajamas if you want.
cons: Unrealistic expectations, No work life balance, the only way to meet expected productivity is to work overtime on a daily basis, audit expectations have increased to a few a month  and are impossible to meet, schedule is changed to their liking with little notice, treated with little respect, not treated like a nurse treated like a telemarketing mule, forced agenda on calls with members, no autonomy, not allowed to voice concern just do the unrealistic impossible expectations that are set for you, average pay, cutting jobs due to the failed merger, extra responsibilities added to the role with no pay incentive, and it's about NUMBERS NUMBERS NUMBERS.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Green Bay, WI
pros: Really focused on wellness for employees and customers.  It truly feels like Humana is moving toward a wellness company instead of just insurance and that is refreshing.  I feel the compensation is just; however, in my experience, the raises are typically 3%, but you can get a better raise if you leave the role and move to a different department (even if it's same title to same title.)
cons: They preach about having an agile work environment and flexible work environment, yet many roles do not offer work at home, or flexible scheules such as 4-10's or core houred shifts.  Due to this, the career opportunities are limited.  There are many roles for which I feel qualified; however, I can't apply because it is not a WAH role and the hiring manager will not consider WAH employees.

pros: Humana is a big company with lots of room for growth.  The company makes a serious effort to be innovative, and we've been in the forefront of the industry for at least the past 7 years.
cons: You'll have to seek out growth opportunities on your own, and you may not get the support you should from your management.  Once inside the company, it's very hard to get fair annual salary increases or even fair increases when moving from one position to the next.  Our HR department is great at employee benefits, but seriously lacking in people management ability.

pros: If you're in Louisville, KY, Humana must be on your short list.   Overall, Humana has a generally good benefit package.  I've worked with both some of the most brilliant and some of the most incompetent people in my career, often at the same time.   Some areas within Humana are fantastic--likely, some of the best in the business.  Just make sure you get into one of those areas of excellence.
cons: A very large organization with not very good coordination.  A very large disconnect between VP and above and directors and below.  Lack of accountability in some areas, especially at the mid-senior level.  Unfortunately, incompetence is tolerated at some areas within the company.

review_title: If you want to advance, go somewhere else
pros: Good benefits, tuition reimbursement, some areas offer flex schedules, three weeks of vacation time plus sick pay, on site fitness center
cons: In order to advance, you really have to know people. You can be the most qualified person for the job, but if you don't personally know the interviewers, you can forget about it. Jobs are posted on the internal job boards even though others have already been offered the position. Why post the jobs if you already know who you want for the position? It's just a waste of time for those putting in for the jobs.

pros: Made some great friends which allowed for good camaraderie. Good 401(k). Good amount of vacation and sick time if you are there long enough
cons: Pay increases are very few and far between, even with great performance. No cost of living increases. Pay is significantly less compared to competitors. Lots of incompentent supervisors and managers who could care less about whether their employees are happy or not. If you want to be rewarded for good performance with a jeans pass, then this is the perfect place to work. Hundreds of jobs were cut and outsourced, so learning how to speak Indian is must before starting employment. Limited opportunities for growth or career advancement, but opportunities are there for those who are part of the right cliques or are "in" with the right people. I could go on but want to avoid ranting.

review_title: Opportunities are endless if you play by the rules...
pros: The financial stability and working remotely is a plus. Humana is a strong insurer with a diverse portfolio. This provides the opportunity to gain market share if you put in the hardwork.
cons: Humana is rapidly progressing into a well-being company. This change has restructured sales and put unrealistic expectations on many departments. Long hours are bad, but no support from management is even worse. Brown-nosing is rewarded, whereas those who want to encourage positive changes are told fall in-line. Middle management is truly a problem that needs to be addressed in order for Humana to be the successful company they have the infrastructure and values to be.

pros: Ability to work from home after 3 months of employment. Generous PTO and 401k plan.
cons: Frequently changing "teams" which includes a new supervisor, every 3-9 months due to turnover. Focus on quantity rather than call quality. Feeling like a zombie, asking questions to meet compliance with CMS, attempting to focus on health of the members but additional pre call and after call documentation becomes time consuming. Long calls with members between 30-60 minutes, then another 30-60 minutes to document. Hard to transition into other roles. Don't feel as though I am actually making a difference with others health, rather asking specific health questions to meet compliance, offering resources (additional work/documentation) that is not taken into consideration. Promoting health of others, but sacrificing one's own health to meet call quantity standards.

review_title: Good stepping stone, but not a career.
pros: Humana has great products and are ahead of the curve with Wellness Capabilities, so its a great place to begin your career in health insurance. They support more flexible work schedules. They approach business in a team model, which provides more support and interaction among co-workers. HumanaVitality is a great program and a huge perk for employees.
cons: They do not take care of their employees. The benefits are not good for a health insurance company. Your development track depends on who likes you in Management and not your talents and contributions. They are not good at communicating internally and that can cause frustration and inefficiencies in your job. Management does not seem very supportive or understanding of the people in the day to day positions.

job_title: Clinical Advisor in New Orleans, LA
pros: Work from home is about the only pro that I can come up with at this time. We have fair Health insurance but it could be better. Volunteer time is offered but only 8 hours a year.
cons: Disrespect for the amount of time put in daily and weekly.  Production numbers are all that is important. They talk about wellness all the time and how we are supposed to be well but there is no time. Stress levels are through the roof. We have no voice. We tell the leaders our concerns but things never change. Being salaried means you work until the numbers are met. It's ridiculous how much pay you actually make per hour when you figure out all the hours that are put in.

job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Cincinnati, OH
pros: medical benefits are ok depending on what plan you choose, decent pay, wellness breaks, nice co-workers, good place work if you looking to pay some bills off or to stack money due to OT opportunity
cons: way too many task for an entry level position, call center=teenage like environment, limited advancement opportunity(beware they hype you up in training), horrible recognition, the worst turn over rate I have ever seen I mean the worst! This is not a good place for "get your foot in the door and move up" you'll be disappointed,  favoritism is the name of the game, its not what you know but who you know and you don't have to know a thing!

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Green Bay, WI
pros: Decent pay if negotiated properly, good amount of vacation time (which can be used pretty infrequently unless requested 3 months in advance), fair attendance policy, some managers are very good (quite few).
cons: Terrible quality auditing, very little opportunity to use vacation time, poorly trained vendor sites, completely irresponsible business practices, broken/inefficient processes, constantly changing policies/processes without giving proper training regarding said changes, rigid corporate structure, continually adding work without giving time to complete, horrible policy of favoritism, no room for advancement without brown nosing.

review_title: Use you and discard you after abusing you
pros: the pay & benefits but they got rid of a lot of us and took on newbies and paid them way less
cons: Do not sacrifice your family life for these users. They won't look at your years of loyalty and production and treat you right when they decide they need to trim staff. They don't value good or loyal employees. They treated employees terribly when they are trying to get rid of them, no matter if they are top producers. They will cut your call volume and then use that to write you up that you have very little production. If you're getting killed with calls while you sit and watch other top producers sitting idly by and you dare to speak up on their behalf, then you become the next target and they don't stop until they eliminate. Not a good environment

review_title: nice job if you're not ambitious
pros: The pay and benefits for a medicare sales representative are great. You're not in an office all day. The Medicare Advantage products are really some of the best around.
cons: Not many opportunities for advancement. Very political. Forced to sell overpriced proprietary products for which you will not be adequately compensated. No set job description-- expected to perform sales, customer service, marketing, provider relations,and clerical functions.

job_title: Customer Care Associate in Green Bay, WI
pros:
Nice co-workers, decent pay for a call center. 
They call off work in inpassable snowstorms.
The downtown location is on a bus route.
cons:
Most front line supervisors are late 20's or early 30's and seem to lack "emotional intellegence".
When the company has a bad year, those who are fired are not "supervisor favorites or peers". If you an older male you are at a disadvantage. Feedback is poor. If they put you on a 'training for improvement' plan you will not get feedback to improve, they are just giving you rope, until they have enough to fire you.
You can earn a decent amount of vacation, but using it without three months notice, or in chunks that include a Monday or a Friday is a problem.

review_title: For Medicare Reps, they hire people by the truckload and have high turnover.
job_title: MarketPoint Sales Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: This is a pretty easy position.  They provied you with leads and only a handful of products you can sell.  When dealing with 60+ people it isa pretty easy sell.
cons: If your manager likes you he/she will provide leads and support.  If not good luck trying to build a book.  I came from the commercial side of healthcare and was not happy with how many reps they had both captive and independent.  Some of the reps were making 6 figures, others were scraping by.

job_title: MarketPoint Sales Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: The pay is good - well it was before they cut it in half a year ago.
cons: Micro management and bullying at it's finest!  Management is trying to turn what used to be a great company into just another recycle bin of used car/insurance agents.  Management very quick to throw you under the bus or exhibit unethical behaviour just to "look good".  You feel like they put a gun to your head every month to hit sales results.  If you don't hit the numbers you are fired or forced to quit.  Very sad - they used to be a good company.

review_title: I regret accepting the offer letter
job_title: Order Entry in West Chester, OH
pros:
- Vacation time wasn't too bad
 - pay wasn't too bad but could be better
cons:
- management openly shows favoritism
- if you question management's ethics, you will be fired
- management doesn't know from one day to another what is going on, what your schedule will be or how to do ANYTHING!
- if management likes you, you can sit and talk for hours, while getting paid and make all the others do the work, get a great schedule and time off whenever you need it.
- it doesn't matter to management if your numbers are the highest, most efficient and accurate.
- No room for growth within department/company
- Conduct redundant group meetings every day unnecessarily, which disrupts work flow.
- Management doesn't provide enough feedback to employees as they say they would.
- Way too many bottlenecks in the department process/operation.

pros:
-Well rounded benefits package:
     Very competitive 401K
     Time off program -23 days per year 
     Tuition assistance up to $5,000 per year
     Vision / Dental / Life Insurance offered
     Employee Assistance Program
     Adoption Assistance
-Company has several initiatives to encourage wellness / well-being including walking challenges with prizes, guest speakers from shows like the Biggest Loser, discounts at gyms, etc.
-A lot of opportunity for growth, development, different career opportunities
-Company believes in pay for performance, cost of living raises do not exist here
cons:
-Cost share of Health Insurance plan can be high - especially for those making under 40K
-Opportunities (both jobs and learning) are plentiful - but the associate themselves has to take charge, this is not mapped out for you

pros:
Humana has a vision that is not only easy to understand, but easy to believe in.  Not only as a vision for a company to achieve, but a vision that I seek to achieve in my day to day life.  I often feel more proud about telling people about all the work other people are doing in our company, than I do talking about anything I do.
Adapting more Agile Working methodologies
Incorporating Well-being into everything we do
Family feel- despite large company
cons: The company is growing rapidly and transforming that large of a company can take time and present hurdles at times. But nothing that we won't overcome over time

review_title: If you are in UX, Visual Designer or Content...RUN!!!
job_title: User Experience, Content Or Visual Designer in Chicago, IL
pros:
Decent pay 
Can work from home once in a while
(these incentives may sounds good during an interview...but read on)
cons:
Insane Design Management
Significant Bullying - Really..it's bad
Request manager to fire an employee because the director didnt like this person (not because of performance)
The director says I like your work, and then talk poorly about it to other people
If you go on an interview, the director is multi-tasking..CONSTANTLY.
Complaints to upper management and HR goes unheard
High Stress, no direction, constant changing of scope and then you are to blame
ZERO Trust in Employees
Constant monitoring
Management 101 issues - Look at any article on bad management, and this person hits every one
Severe Mood Shifts
Your Glass is never half-full..ok it's a nice way to say your intelligence is always in question
Micromanages EVERYTHING
Everyday you feel like you might get fired

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Louisville, KY
pros: I worked for Humana Tricare division, who are a group of folks committed to serving the needs of our country's veterans and active duty service members. Special care was taken to ensure these military personnel recieved the benefits they so richly deserve. Senior leadership always takes the time to speak to you personally. My CEO made his own coffee, even though he had a line of secretaries to pass on his way to the break room. The corporate office is beautiful and sits right in downtown, which is a nice area to work. Camdaraderie among the Tricare division is something I really miss.
cons: Elimination of annual raises. Parking so far from the office! The two inch candy cane for a Christmas gift. Seriously?

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Good products and compensation packages for sales agents, especially the Medicare market. So, so products for traditional individual major medial insurance. Flexible working hours.
cons: Management has set sales goals way to high and only about 10% acually achieve goals on a monthly basis. Management will not hesitate to trheaten you with termination for not producing.
