The focus on sales goals are products that they compensate the sales agent the least. Underwriting is a nightmare and folks are rarely approved for coverage. Very high rates on Medicare supplements.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in De Pere, WI
pros: Pay was ok, Benefits and perks were pretty great. If you luck out and are assigned to a 'specialized' team (like pharma, ASO or home-office) you are instantly under a lot less stress as the call volume goes way down, you're either dealing with people who do the same thing you do or are dealing with people that have amazing benefits.
cons: Their HR policies are insufferably rigid. They lose amazing talent all the time thanks to rigid attendance policies and no empathy. Employ/train someone for a couple weeks, they do something HR doesn't like and they aren't warned twice. Out the door and an awkward conversation piece for future interviews.

review_title: Assessment of current employer, Censeo Health
job_title: Physician Evaluator in New Orleans, LA
pros: The Pros of my position as a Physician Evaluator with Censeo was the opportunity to connect with Seniors of every race, creed, color, size and socioeconomic status. The opportunity to give compassionate care to each individual was a blessing.
cons: The challenge of my work with Censeo was the requirement of driving long distances to see members. During my last few months of work I not only drove to Shreveport and  Natchitoches, but the  distance from the hotel to the member's home was an additional hour. I must say, once I arrived at the home, I completely forgot that experience. I accepted the cups fresh coffee as I laughed, answered questions and encouraged members to take care for themselves as a part of the team.

review_title: Senior Management is headed in the right direction. Management under the Senior level, really needs serious help.
job_title: IT Tech Architect in Louisville, KY
pros: Time off. My position allows me to have plenty of time off. Perfect Service might just pay off too. Its a great concept, but its really pathetic that Humana had to go to another company to figure out how to make its employees and, more importantly, its subscribers happy.
cons: The saying, "Its hard to teach an old dog new tricks" holds true at Humana. A majority of the management has been with the company for decades and trying to get management to install new policies is hell! ITIL has been in the "works" for 3 years now and not much has changed.

review_title: Overall a decent job but does get tiring pretty quickly
pros:
- Growing company (my division)
- Good benefits
- Pretty good at sticking to a 40 hour work week with some flexibility
- Nice "campus" in terms of gym, cafeteria, etc.
cons:
- It's a large company, so nobody actually cares about you.  You can be one of the most diligent workers, but the middle management will always find something to criticize you or your team for.
- Management is EXTREMELY overdone.  They monitored bathroom breaks, if that gives you an indication of how much they micromanage.
- Management also never truly takes any of your ideas into consideration no matter how good they are unless they asked you to do it as a "side project" and expect you to still do all your other work to its general capacity as well.

review_title: Inside sales, more like not paid for sales
job_title: Inside Sales Executive in Middleton, WI
pros: Friends you meet, take as many walks as you want
cons: Head of the National Sales Office sits in office and practices put swing when not on the golf course (this is weekly). His two right hand men that are in charge of other managers that are your managers, do the same. They, well no one knows what they do.  Departments don't talk to each other.  Commissions do not get paid, they get taken back because they change the rules in the company...They don't want insurance experience or someone who can speak for themselves...you have to use your badge to go to the bathroom, yes they monitor when and how many times you go to the bathroom..

pros: Above average pay with a great focus on the well-being of associates.  (IE - They truly seem to care about our us as employees).  If associate is struggling or unhappy, management tends to work to find the best fit for the associate; I've seen several instances where associates have been re-assigned to other roles based on their skill set, rather than just cast aside.  This is comforting as the business climate ebbs and flows.
cons: MASSIVE company.  Sheer size of the company often hinders "team" feeling.  Benefits are just average, but below what you would expect from an insurance company.   Teams are often scattered all over the country/world, therefore it becomes difficult to build comradery.

review_title: I am glad I work here
pros: Puts their money where their mouth is for company values.  Encourage employee wellness and work/life balance.  I like having an employee credit card instead of having to spend my own money and expense it.  I like working from home.  I think the benefits are very good.  I think the company is run professionally and has the expectation that employees behave professionally and at a high standard.  I feel that the associates I have seen hired are high quality.
cons: This is a large organization with a lot of legal and regulatory considerations.  Therefore, decisions for change are slow.  I don't feel that my ideas would necessarily be up for consideration.  I do feel like a cog in the wheel vs. a creative part of the organization.  Sometimes it is so "corporate" that it feels intimidating.

review_title: Not the Best but FAR from the worst
pros: My Frontline leader and manager are approachable. No micro Managing. PTO requests are almost always granted. Layed back environment for the most part. Option to Work from home or in office after training is completed.
cons: Most departments do NOT follow a SOP(Standard Operating Procedure); therefore some people within the same dept. are doing the same job several different ways. At times your direct frontline lead cant answer your inquiries; therefore you may have to educate yourself, wait a while for a response, or try the "trial and error" method.

pros:
Work at home opportunities
Tuition reimbursement
401k matching
cons:
Appallingly terrible medical benefits
Out-of-touch Senior Management
Great disparity/favoritism shown between departments and locations (i.e. bonus-earning opportunities given to some dept's but not others, etc.)
Meager raises for hourly associates
Doesn't believe in boosting morale or rewarding non-management associates for a job well done
Permanent hiring freeze in some departments which leads to short-staffing and overworked/underpaid associates
Does not offer floating holidays nor close on Christmas Eve or day after Christmas

job_title: Care Manager in Wesley Chapel, FL
pros: Humana has great benefits for employees. You can earn points which turn in to cash by keeping healthy and setting goals. I got a fit bit.surge this way at no cost to me. You can work from home so no more traffic jams.lots of opportunities to move around in company.
cons: Computer and phones go down a lot which can be very frustrating. The work load is never ending. Policies change very quickly . A lot to keep up with and not alot of support.

pros: Humana is a very large company that can either be a career or great to build your resume'. The opportunity to advance in the company is always there. The work environment is nice and most facilities have a workout area. The salary is decent and can give bonuses in most departments based on performance. Benefits are OK but Humana pushes for a healthy lifestyle and promotes it well. Management pushes for success and are always willing to help. Working from home is encouraged after 6 months.
cons: The specialist jobs can be very difficult, not the actual work, but the how much production you must work with in a day. Some of the departments have a high turnover rates due to that situation. Working Saturday's is very common along with holidays. Raises can be difficult to get unless you get promoted.

review_title: Great company for work at home opportunity.
pros: Good training, provide the equipment and set up costs. Helping clients navigate health needs by using the insurance money was a nice task.
cons: Lots of internal changes, reorganization from teams to new rosters of client/members every few months. Unrealistic goals to meet production criteria when people won't answer their phones. Have to sit in a cubical (call center) for first 30 days.

pros: The great thing about working with Humana other than having benefits is able to be updated with other skills sets. Humana is one of the few companies that will be willing to help you with school and even have you trained, they will even pay for the test. As a company value its great. I recommend it for those who look to better themselves in the long-run
cons: Management is not the best and I think that is pretty sad in comparison to a company as big as Humana. I honestly don't know what to say other than management is not so efficient. You are a number and if you want to move up the corporate later you have to go to more than just your manager you need to talk to multiple people and be heard.

pros: The benefits are good and start day one. Also they offer great education assistance.
cons: Treat hard working employees like they are dispensable. Do everything in their power to ensure certain people receive raises. Confusing instructions and day to day last minute changes. Managers speak to you unprofessionally. They dont every want you to take time off no matter the reason. Expectations to be perfect are extremely high.

pros: None that I can really think of, which is why myself and many, many more talented and experienced individuals are leaving. You can only work so long without recognition and opportunities before you look elsewhere.
cons: Employee insurance programs are expensive and offer minimal coverage. Had to purchase coverage from a competitor to get better healthcare that we could afford. Management is secretive and does not share future plans, or even encourage that there is a future given the merger is in hold. Any information shared is gained through local media coverage. No faith in CEO and upper management. News reports reflect huge golden parachutes for their futures, but not such a golden futures for those trying hard to keep their jobs and take care of their families.

pros:
- Industry that impacts people's health and lives.
- Committed to digital excellence
- Friendly, helpful co-workers
cons:
- Industry transition. Lots of changes due to ACA and other dynamics
- Very uneven middle management leadership quality
- Job descriptions are at variance with the actual work being done
- Middle management heavy leads to lots of confusion
- Layers of bureaucracy to get created work implemented
- Copywriter position is saddled with more copy management and reporting to middle managers than actual writing. Position is saddled with shepherding copy through the business, marketing and corporate review processes. 
-Trying hard to switch from Waterfall PM to Agile PM with very limited and uneven success. Highly stressful

review_title: Humana is a good stepping stone into the insurance business
pros: Management track, flex time, opportunities for growth. Many opportunities if you work hard, and also they take into consideration what area you enjoy working in.  They also are starting to have more people work from home which can be great for those with small children.
cons: At times felt like factory work, or like you were in school still the way you were watched but probably necessary because some people take advantage.  If you have a sick child it can be difficult to take time away from work, again some people take advantage so they are very strict on sick time.

pros: Work from home...unless you're in leadership. Retirement match is great.  Co-workers in helping professions are kind.
cons: No confidence in upper management - recent changes are a regression and show a lack of vision.  The only innovative program has only one associate.  Clinical department is in shambles and behind two years running. Manipulative tactics to rate high on Engagement surveys: a strong member-focus two months leading up to the survey, but after the survey it's all about the numbers. Lots of opportunities posted - and filled by external candidates.

pros: .Good salary and good benefits.  Lots of PTO available.
cons: When I started about 18 months ago it was fine, low stress and good boss.  Fast forward to now and Aetna is buying them out and everything has changed.  Now it's all about productivity, they want you to be stuck to the phones all day.  Even when you bust your butt calling and you can't reach their daily productivity, it doesn't matter because they expect more and more and more.  They have about 15 different measures and if you don't meet one you're not doing well.  No support from upper management.  They promise room to grow, but realistically, it's not there.

review_title: I have enjoyed everyday working for this company, even amidst a variety of changes.
pros: Vision, values, virtual ability and agile working environments, flexibility and the great close work family mentality, low turn over in my area, benefits of retirement account matching %, 8 VTO hours per year
cons:
Ever changing processes can be challenging. hr is at times too soft on the ccip enforcement. Too many poorly performing associates are kept on for way too long-term, causing exhaustion for the leaders and the mind set of giving up on calling hr for those who are less than average performers. 

Well being focused or not, enough is enough, thses people are paid to work, and work is not what they are doing, causing trouble and getting away with it, and getting paid is what they are doing.

pros:
Great opportunity to work for a large organize and rack up some good (on paper) experience.
Able to work with a few great people who have a passion for what they do, although management does not share the same sensibility.
cons:
As another reviewer said, management changes processes weekly. The Aetna Merger coming has made it all about the numbers when it used to be about the members. Humana has started to loose its identity. 
Work/Life balance depends on your manager and is not baked into company culture. If your manager is having a bad week than so are you. 
Benefits are surprisingly lacking.

pros: the pay is good and they provided me with training to get applicable licensing, and paid the associated fees to do so. initially I was proud to be a part of the company, but their products have decreased while their prices have exponentially increased, leaving customers alienated and bitter, and looking elsewhere for better offers. There was a time I really believed in the promises, but it is now hard for me to speak highly of the company when they are heading down a path I so disagree with.
cons: The managers huddle in shared incompetence, afraid to allow any one with logic and reasoning skills into a position of authority, since it will then reflect back on how much more poorly the existing management staff performs.

review_title: Cube farm, decent benefits, good place to learn and grow
pros: Humana has decent benefits; three weeks vacation, health insurance, good work/life balance, and tuition reimbursement.  They have a half of 6% 401k match.  The management is okay and compensation is decent.  It is a good place to learn and grow and gain experience working in a lot of different areas from data to finance.  If you come in on time and work hard there shouldn't be any problem moving up.  I usually don't work more than 40 hours a week and rarely are there really stressful times.
cons: It is a cube farm and it is very politically correct.  There are no company wide bonuses.  Things can get really boring at times.

pros: The education reimbursement program is amazing if you are going for a MBA. There are mutliple departments/organizations within Humana to move into (if you can). There is the ability to have some additional training (if available). There is a high importance placed on customer experience.
cons: There is a lack of feedback during reviews. HR has no placement program if looking to move outside of department. Main concern: working environment differs greatly between departments. This is probably the biggest reason people. Additional training may not be available, even if requested. Culture very dependent on senior management in specific department.

review_title: Be careful of which area you apply to
job_title: Applications Consultant in Green Bay, WI
pros: Competitive salary. Work from home flexibility. As a large company, it has resources that smaller companies do not have and can try new things even if risky. Awesome career growth opportunity ATM.
cons: No one escapes the politics. The hours you must work each week can be super high depending on where in the company you work. It really depends on who you're working for. The company is large enough that each department can feel like a different smaller company.

pros:
-Good place to start and build knowledge to take elsewhere.
-Fast growing industry
-Pro healthy lifestyle programs
-401K match very attractive
cons:
-Too many hands in the pot.  No clear lines of responsibility allows all associates to shirk responsibility, leaving customers with the bill.
-Poor communication and territorial battles between departments.
-Unprofessional conduct. VP's openly discuss their right wing politics and religion in public, often using vulgar, offensive, racist, sexist, homophobic language.  
-Employee training...you're on your own.
-Terrible Health Insurance coverage.
-Good Ole Boy system.  Management positions go to those with highest level of incompetence.
-IT stuck in the last century.  Duplication of databases means duplication of work..designed to build independent department kingdoms.
-Sales goals unrealistic.
-Nearly impossible for customers to resolve billing issues resulting in high member turnover.

review_title: Humana has been good to me
pros: Great company, depending on the department you work in.  Very flexible in terms of hours.  I know people who have not had much success while working for this company and I also know people who love this company.  I happen to love it!  I know I can leave and make about 20% more salary but I've learned a lot while working here and I also enjoy the flexibility.
cons: If possible, know the fair market price for the role you are going after, make sure you stick firm to your asking starting salary.  Most years I do get a raise but it's not much.

job_title: Item Entry EPOST SME in Glendale, AZ
pros: Overtime, pot lucks, the 2 bonuses we got, pto, the associates who tried to make a change, the associates that refused to cheat numbers though everyone else was, the associates who stood up for what's right and not lie and cheat like leadership for the numbers.
cons: Leadership was always fighting, gossiping, about each other. We always heard them... They never really worked. I wish they had to show what they accomplished each dat. That would be hilarious

pros: Helping Medicare members meet personal goals.
cons:
LifeSynch Humana Achieve
Toxic work environment
Low salary
Added responsibility on an almost daily basis
Metrics are more important than members' needs
Degrading remarks from management
Constant threats of termination
After almost 8 years of employment, I was terminated for being accused of "not meeting their business needs".  I chose to focus on my members' needs.  Being terminated was a freeing experience.  No more severe headaches, less chronic pain, no more anxiety, no more dirty looks from FLLs, & the depression has miraculously lifted.  They are diligently firing anyone who has more than 5 years of service.  Ethics have gone out the window.  Established members are being ignored for the sake of more activations.  They are getting rid of all Master level associates in order to hire Bachelor level people at lower salaries.  All of the remaining Master level clinicians are moving to other departments or leaving the company at a rapid rate.  This company needs to be investigated!

review_title: Referral Specialist or Referral Intake Team
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Lots of PTO, health insurance, dental, vision.  Monday through Friday hours and holidays paid.
cons: The position I worked was telemarketing even though the service being offered over the phone is free.  It was absolutely mind numbing doing the same thing over and over and from what I understand moving up from the position takes a couple of years although you are eligible to apply to other positions 6 months in.  I chose to return to my previous employer after hitting my wall.  The pay was average and it is an entry level position.  Not for anyone with a personality and definitely made me an unhappy person each moment I was there.

review_title: Great company, but poor in mentoring employees. Penalizes employee for leaving company.
pros: You are exposed to other areas of responsibilities outside of your own. Anyone who hires an former Humana employee would benefit from the vastness of ther experiences.
cons:
It is very difficult to be promoted.
Company does not  believe in rehiring former employees.
Salary is average, and percentage of increase is limited and departments has a maximum amount of monies designated for performance increases, so most managers scale performance reviews to fall within the requirements, meanwhile they "rob Peter to pay Paul" in order to keep within the budget. Thus create an imbalance.

review_title: Good for outside coming in....no so much for internal
pros: Descent hours and work like balance.  Wonderful people to work with and steady employment.
cons: You have to fight with HR for raises. Instead of your role being a promotion, they will tell you it's an extention of your current role.  By doing this the pay increase if very minimal.  Coming in the company externally, you're taken care of.  Internally you're not.

review_title: STARS Outreach specialist looking for advancement
job_title: Stars Pharm Outreach Spec in Louisville, KY
pros: Great Benefits and Compensation and opportunity for growth
cons: don't cross train on company systems which does hinder some growth opportunities

review_title: Great company if you end up with the right team
job_title: Front-End Technical Lead in Louisville, KY
pros:
Benefits and salary are better than what you will get from most other companies; no matter what your role is.

There are plenty of challenges to overcome and problems to solve when it comes to marketing and IT.

If you end up on the right team, you will have a boss that truly does care about your well-being and promoting a fair work-life balance. 

There are plenty of opportunities available to grow professionally within the company.
cons:
Mostly because it is the health insurance industry, many times bureaucracy and process will get in the way and cause tasks to take longer to accomplish. 

If you end up on the wrong team, you will be miserable.

review_title: Humana is a great company to work for, but some departments have opportunities for improvement.
job_title: Process Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros: Humana offers educational, networking, work-life balance, and volunteering opportunities. The Humana values brings life to the meaning of humanity and advocate well-being for all.
cons: Certain departments are not aligned with the values and mission of company. Lack of Goals and expectations for each role, but implement coaching to performance prior to clearly indicating the purpose of each team and the department. More discussions are held to identify failures, than to identify ways to develop and create success. Consistently operate in a retroactive state than proactively.

pros:
Great people friendly knowledgeable and professional
401K plan was amazing with a $1.25 match up to 6%
Opportunity to work with all levels across departments
Work at home is a nice to promote work/life balance
Travel perks as far as points and status are good 
They do try an put member first day to day
cons:
Very political at some levels or in some departments 
Not enough value on non clinical employees 
Pay is lower than competitors 
Very disorganized at leadership level post Aetna block
Uneven work distribution

pros: My opinion matters and my voice is heard. In a Fortune 100 environment, that is not often the case. But here at Humana, everyone is on the same team and I come to work each day and make a difference. My colleagues are my friends, my work is exciting, and the environment is rich in culture and success is yours if you're willing to own it. As long as my work matters, I plan to be here for many many years.
cons: The biggest detractor about Humana is that it oftentimes feels too big of a company. Meaning, trying to push a project forward, there are too many "cooks in the kitchen." I understand the purpose of a collaborative approach, but sometimes a decision requires too many people to buy-in.

review_title: Difficult to obtain opportunities of advancement.  Little to none of annual pay increase.
pros: Great family report with associates excluding upper management.  Starting salaries are immaculate.  Employee appreciations and pot lucks happen often to bring morale.  Two years in a row all associates received a tax free 1000 Christmas bonus.  Horrible medical benefits.
cons: Job opportunity advancement is lateral moves.  You are advised to follow compliance yet you may be stuck on a call and liable to cut your short to maintain stats.  Micromanagement is in effect with customer service associates.  You can anticipate mandatory overtime.  A lock for no movement meaning you can not apply for other positions until the lock is removed (may take up to 2 years).  Lots of sexual discrimination from management, that is if your a women.

review_title: Expect everything but give nothing, not family friendly or flexible to employees needs
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Green Bay, WI
pros: You get a paycheck, and good health benefits
cons: They are not flexible at all for families and giving time off for illness, emergencies, etc. when my elderly parents had to relocate recently, I asked for a leave of absence to assist and was denied!!! the only thing they see is the business need with such tunnel vision, that any personal circumstances are ignored. Avoid this employer at all costs unless you are single, and have no other life!!!

pros: Pretty good technology and technical support for employees. Some good wellness programs. Pretty good work/life balance.
cons: A high performer who proved themselves year after year and was never given an opportunity to advance. They offer good benefits but the rates increased significantly year over year and Humana did little to cover any of the expense. Compensation, unless you're in management, is significantly below industry standard. Turnover is high and they do nothing about it. Management consistently hires candidates that are a poor fit and do not have the skills necessary to do the job. They do very little to keep their hourly employees engaged. It's definitely a "good old boys" club.

pros: name recognition of fortune 500 company, that's it
cons: too many people in all levels of the company that have attained their position through politics and not through performance or results. There are many people in the company that are "the only one that can do what they do" because people horde information as if it were the ring of power. It is impossible to run effective projects there due to the sheer incompetence of Humana associates. For the most part, I have rarely seen anyone in the company follow prescribed PMI project methodology.

review_title: Great Company to work for, but still a BIG company
pros: Humana has great benefits (401K matching, HSA, and wellness incentives).  Most of my coworkers are happy in their positions.  I am in an entire department that works from home which is great for a lot of moms and people who want to have autonomy and flexible hours.
cons: It's hard to get a raise or promotion.  In the 3 years I've been here I've received 1 tiny raise.  Trying to get a new idea "approved" or implemented is a circus act.  I wish there was more support for professional growth and "moving up".

pros: Work at home opportunity - more companies should consider this..
cons:
Expensive health insurance benefits
No growth opportunity unless you live in Louisville KY
Excessive coaching with lots of contradictions - they dig for things to criticize in your performance just to be seen to be "coaching" That is neither effective nor "coaching"...
Pompous leaders who are self important, smug and preening - talk down to nurses as if we are all simple minded. 
Present ridiculous concepts as "exciting challenges" and expect us to be excited. 
Evaluation system is onerous and overly complicated and fails to reflect your actual performance in any way. 
Horrible documentation system.

review_title: Great place to work, plenty of opportunities... if you can overcome the challenges of a large company.
pros:
- Excellent senior management, communication strategy is polished and effective
- Plenty of internal growth opportunities, if you can uncover them
- Growing (for now), health care reform may change that
- Large company (lots of resources at your disposal), just use them wisely
- Great work / life balance
cons:
- Health care reform (high uncertainty), but not any worse than other companies in this industry
- Highly regulated industry 
- High dependency on Medicare book of business
- Large company (silos, and information bottlenecks)
- IT is a good 5 years behind current standards

review_title: Health insurance benefit is ironically among the worst
pros: 401(k) benefit seems generous.  Good cultures and work environments exist in some departments (mostly operations and IT).  Location in downtown Louisville is nice.
cons: Employee health insurance benefit is an insult and is loaded with additional fees and administrative requirements.  Salaries are well below comparable organizations.  IT is a step or two behind other Fortune 500 companies (we just stopped using Lotus Notes last year, and blackberries remain the norm).  Many departments are very political (favoritism and lack of transparency in hiring) and many managers are very traditional (e.g., requirement to wear suits to the office, "face time" expected -- even for employees who could otherwise work remotely).  Diversity is practically non-existent (think old, white guys with little creativity).

pros: Humana is very progressive with rewards, bonuses, and compensation. There are opportunities for advancement if you have the ability to market yourself and your abilities. A great fit for a corporate-savvy self-starter. The corporate enterprise goals are inspiring, and there are a multitude of employee perks and incentives - including several excellent well-being programs and a great benefits package.
cons: The daily work environment varies considerably depending on the department you work in, and even within the same department, the work environment can vary from supervisor to supervisor. It may not be a good fit for someone who places a high value on consistency. It's not the worst place the work, but it has a tendency to burn through employees due to inconsistent management, and the excellent corporate messages and initiatives tend to get overlooked on a local level.

review_title: Do not quit and try to re-apply,won't happen!
pros: Great company to work for ,great benefits except health plan.
cons: For being a health insurance company, they have a terrible health plan for the lower level non management career employees. Also if you consider anything about quitting and wanting to come back for full time employment,forget it! they told me it couldn't be done. It did not matter to local management that I was the number one Medicare salesperson with several awards ,salesman of the month etc.. I had to become an Independent contractor otherwise known as a MECA agent.Guess what? there are other insurance companies that will hire you with my background and experience. I now work for United Healthcare

pros: Work at Home, 401-k good match, industry leader in telephonic case management. Good Team support. Tuition, but no time to use it. A few excellent coaches.
cons: Micro-management, top heavy  and continue to add more staff to monitor. Salaried staff time managed down to minutes and seconds. Time spent on adjusting to new daily requirements, and learning new processes and meetings to discuss same, infringe on time to meet the quantity-only based metrics. Quality diluted and losing good staff and customers. Future uncertain with merger.  Many providers quit accepting insurance.

pros: Work from home and PTO
cons: Lack of flexibility in work schedule.  Salaried employees cannot take partial PTO days to go to appts.  Must take an entire day off or make up every minute you are gone to get 8 hours in per day.  Very micromanaged by management and multiple managers doing the same things.  Too many chiefs and not enough indians.  Focus is on quantity and not quality in order to meet the unrealistic expectations.  Many already laid off and unsure of future at this employer

review_title: MBA crazy, Disorganized, All about Checking Boxes.
pros: Good amount of vacation time.  Work at home depends on your manager.
cons: They market a lot of things they don't actually provide to employees.  There are scores of people that legitimately won't have work for days/weeks.  Ridiculous amount of double work being done because of silos.  Most people try to outrun their mistakes up the ladder.

pros: The company used to offer bonus's for the holidays but that stopped. They also have a lot of room for growth with this company. they work with you to enhance your career if that's the path you want to take, and they offer certain work from home positions.
cons: The sick time and health benefits suck. You are micro managed and you will have several managers with in a year at this company, and this makes it hard to get to know who your working for. There is always the possibility of lay off''s in certain areas during the downtime of the year.

job_title: Field Care Manager in Charleston, WV
pros: The pros working for Humana were some insurance perks. My husband is a diabetic and we received his insulin for free.
cons: The changes to "non-policies" that are left up to each manager happen not only on a day to day basis but also by case manager to case manager basis. If the case managers talk to each other they find they are being told to do things differently and then the manager knows who is talking to who by what they say to her that others have been told to do.

review_title: If you can handle being talked to my 95% of the members like you aren't even worth a penny, take the job.
job_title: Customer Service Representative Mail Order Pharmacy in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
Humana itself is a wonderful company.
My manager was extremely understanding and lenient.
Some members are actually nice and appreciative.
cons:
Only a half hour for lunch.
The members are some of the most disrespectful and blatantly rude people I have met in my life.
Doctors mess up everything and are even less respectful than the members.
Most of the other people in management in my department are catty and no matter how much you go to HR about them, nothing gets done.
Out of my training class from October, at least five of us myself included have had to seek therapy due to the mental issues this job causes.

review_title: Humana is a good place to work
pros: the sales compensation was competitive, benefits were good, local leadership was good. Most of the employees are true contributors to the team.  Training and learning opportunities are abundant.
cons: management is not always in touch with reality as it relates to their specific markets.  goal setting is done at the cororate level and market trends are not always considered when making goal adjustments.

pros: Salary, commitment to members and each other. Great facilities. The company has a lot of great ideas in the Healthcare space and is very innovative.
cons: Concerned about health of members, but not each other. Constant lunch time meetings mean you cannot use your gym membership at the corporate facilities that you pay for. The red tape involved in the simplest task makes you want to gouge your eyes out.

pros:
•	Great work-life balance
•	Strong focus on the health of associates
•	Decent benefits
•	Ability to work from home in some roles
•	Good opportunities for professional development
cons:
•	Employee experience varies widely from one area to another. While the area I’m in is wonderful, I have other family members who work for Humana who are miserable due to poor management, high stress environments, and poor work-life balance. 
•	It’s can be difficult to advance. You almost have to know about a job before it’s posted and then know someone who can get you an interview. No help from HR.

review_title: Humana is fun if you like being a corporate drone.
pros: All the benefits are great, but surprisingly they don't offer very good insurance plans for being an insurance company.
cons: Humana is structured in such a way that it takes ages to get things done because it must go through all the appropriate approvals.  Also, don't expect to advance quickly in the company because it is not performance oriented - they put more emphasis on experience.  Also, advancement tends to be more lateral than vertical.  The last thing I want to comment on is the corny employee summits they have.  They are designed to make you feel good about the company, but they are superficial and just awkward.

pros: One of the things that attracted me to Humana was their commitment to great customer service.  The corporate offices in Green Bay truly fulfilled this promise.
cons:
Humana's health premiums and renewals were very high compared to competitors in the industry.  It was very apparent that the focus was on profitability versus growth.  I'm all for making a profit, but a philosophy that should be adopted would be - Sell more for less.  To me their goal is just the opposite of that statement.  

While they provided excellant customer service to their external customers, they did not extend this same sentiment to their own employees.  Compensation would be inaccurate, HR would not return calls when promised, management did not support employees ideas.

review_title: Very high salary right out of an MBA makes for great internship/1st-job, No-Promotion/Raise policy makes for short stay
pros:
Some of the nicest people in the world work at Humana

9:45-4:45 office culture means you'll have plenty of time out side of work

The cafeteria is second to none

Extensive on-boarding and "development opportunities" leads to a great esprit de corps among infusion associates and a bond that most carry with them when they leave.

COMPENSATION!!! I've never been paid so much to do so little.
cons:
Humana is a tight-knit organization in a tight-knit town. The most common question asked in your first week is "where did you go to school?" They don't mean grad-school or even college; they mean high-school. If you did go to high-school in Kentucky, take the job.

If you didn't, I suggest you keep reading.

It isn't to say that Humana isn't a nice place to be, it just means that you will have to be there a LONG time to effect any type of change or career progression. The data bares this out: despite having 15-20 Masters students coming in at one or two levels below Director, only one Infusion Associate has ever been promoted up to that level. The program has been running since 2004. 

That wouldn't be all bad except for the fact that Humana has a performance incentive plan that make little sense and bears no resemblance to how such matters are handled at other large firms. (It is literally too complicated to explain here. Sufficient to say that a complete performance review cycle takes 18 months.) The result is an informal "No-Raise" policy for Infusion Associates. Don't worry though, you get a 4th week of paid-vacation after 7 years of service.

Moreover, Humana has a history of brutal workforce reductions. I came in one morning to hear that they fired 20% of the marketing department. If you didn't baby-sit for your VP when you were in high-school, you have no political cover and Infusion Associates make easy targets. 10% of my Infusion class was fired within 5 months of starting.

But the introductory compensation is pretty great: on average $5K-$15K more than MBA would receive going into a health-care consulting role. The discussion will likely not start out that way as "Humana doesn't negotiate offers" but...well...if you believe that, you deserve $95K/year.

And all that money comes with very little expected in return. The key insight is that Humana is not a Fortune 100 company; it's a small Kentucky health-plan that got extraordinarily lucky by stumbling onto a federal program early. As a result, they don't have a true need for young talent who are prepared to lead small initiatives because the place is still run like a rotary club; You're either an SVP or a project manager. 

But at the end of the day, it's not very hard work. So you have plenty of opportunity to wander around and learn how a large health-insurance company works. You also get a nice title on your resume and a great salary off which you can benchmark future offers.  All this leaves you very well prepared to take a much higher paying job in a much more desirable city working with much more intelligent people after you've been in the job for a year and the pre-pay penalty associated with the signing bonus drops off.

Don't worry, you won't be alone. 
Approximately 50% of my infusion class was gone within 13 months of starting at the company.

review_title: They talk the talk but can't walk the walk.
job_title: Company Contact Lead in Cincinnati, OH
pros: I was able to help people with their insurance issues.  I did this by providing education and guidance.  They are a large company and have a lot of opportunities once hired.
cons: They are very shiny on the outside but not so sweet on the inside.  They have a very cookie cutter image and don't respond well to those who do not fit into that mold.  Advancement becomes difficult.  The benefits are terrible considering they are an insurance company.  Internal customer service is borderline rude and often not very helpful.  As employees, we are expected to go above and beyond to offer the ultimate customer service experience but as the consumer that is far from what happens.

pros: Being able to work from home
cons: Worst company I have ever worked for in my 10 years of Nursing. They promise you the world: well-being time, great work/life balance...WRONG! In reality, you work 10 to 12 hours every day in an effort to meet NUMBERS! And some days of no one answers, you don't meet your metrics. Then, you get singled out. Get singled out for asking for more help/resources. You get blessed out for posting how you feel on BUZZ, the company website where employees network. Upper management or HR cares nothing about you. All the care about is the big fat bonuses they get for killing their employees. I have never hated a job more in my life. It is hell. You are given a time limit on how long you can talk to these members, time limit to document. Every call, keystroke, everything is monitored. Coaches are micromanagers. My best advice is do not work here. Save yourself the heartache and misery.

pros: Working from home was very nice.
cons: I had 200 people that I had to call every month:  leaving the same message up to 15x for the same person in that month, along with my successful calls which may take up to one hour depending on their acuity. I had metrics to meet every month or else I would be sanctioned by my manager & at the end of the year that would mean no raise.  So I would work beyond my usual hours per day to make my calls in order to meet my metrics. It was a very stress filled job from Humana always adding new programs which added new metrics every month to the computer glitches on an almost daily basis slowing calls to micromanaging coaches also causing more stress. Good luck if you choose Humana.

job_title: Clinical Advisor in Green Bay, WI
pros: Work from home, salary competitive
cons: Sneaky leaders, demeaning, bully like at times, big brother like management of time inappropriate for licensed professionals.   The health insurance could be better.  Unable to take vacation time as requested.  Multiple times denied or forced to do flex time rather than actual vacation time.  Mandated Overtime is not unusual; especially during summer / near holidays when employees would love to enjoy Work life balance but can not.

job_title: Billing and Reconciliation Representative III in Louisville, KY
pros: Its a huge company so it has a lot of perks! They have some really cool benefits. You can earn lots of free stuff with your medical benefits for being healthy!
cons: Again its a big company so sometimes moving up can be hard unless you really get in with the right person. I was there for 6 years and seen several people advance because they became best friends with a Supervisor or Manager to move up. I am not the kind of person to make fake friends to move up. So I was left behind many times because I was not part of the "In Crowd"

review_title: They Want A Creepy Level of Information
pros: Very well-being minded company with a great atmosphere that allows you to work from home when necessary or at all possible.
cons: The company encourages employees to get fit by setting goals that others often know and encouraging the wearing of step-trackers.  Their security is so elaborate that if you stop to think about how many passwords you eventually go through (Humana has you create a new one pretty often) and how much they know about their employees health then they could likely know so much about you it's almost scary.

pros: The people I work with are particularly great! Customer Service positions tend to have nicer people working in them.
cons: Team was completely digital, hard to have workplace activities or workplace friendships... hurts morale, a lot.

pros:
Pay well
Work at home in many positions
Average benefits but not considering they are a health insurance company
No other
cons:
Micro managing
Non transparent
Forced contacts to members who did not want to be contacted
Presents with spins on information, won't answer questions directly
Over hired then laid off extensively
Prior to lay off, began finding fault with staff so they became ineligible for severance although CEO making $79 million?
When staff began quitting, offered a new list of benefits but if you consider what they really are it only amounted to 2 more days off each year.
Promoting managers who support/practice these methods.

review_title: Fantastic company to work for; clear defined mission statement and values - and the values are lived every day!
pros: Flexible working (work at home option for most corporate employees), great benefits, plenty of opportunities to move up or over, fantastic culture of promoting well-being
cons: Work/life balance can be a little hard to maintain. It's never verbally stated, but you'll definitely get some sideways glances if you come in at 8 and leave at 5 everyday and don't check your email at home.

pros: Direct manager is very flexible with schedule. Has a direct desire to help grow in career position. She has no support with leadership above her at NSO in Madison
cons: Extreme micro management from "leadership" highest level of management at NSO just sit in offices listen to calls and try and find ways to fire people rather than working to help build a positive atmosphere and recognize the hard work people do.

pros: Great TV commercials. Excellent food service center in Louisville.
cons: The left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. Awful communication between upper mgmt & employees. Completely disorganized. Treats employees with absolute disrespect. No raises. Employee reviews are a joke. Favoritism everywhere. If someone is fired, other employees are not allowed to speak to them. Regional mkt director displays bully-like behavior and gets pleasure out of harassing others. Stay far, far away. The morale is so low in Louisville & Chicago. So many people unhappy & looking for jobs. Salary is on the low side too.

review_title: These women are backstabbing high school mentality adults (age wise)
pros: Flexible schedule, work from home,
cons: even though Humana employs women, which is good...these women are stabbing and scheming against any new female employee that appears to be a threat to their careers...The new hires have a lot of experience, education, but these Humana career women are terrifying and team-up, bad-mouth, slander any employee after they are driven out...Hostile, hostile, HOSTILE, these women withhold information that is vital to their jobs...they are cold, nasty, mean-spirited, NOT APPROACHABLE, rude, vicious!!!! Do companies hold senior management accountable for attaching, scapegoating, slandering, attacking, gossiping, backstabbing, humiliating, tormenting, inhumane humana behaviors? They are terrible!!!

review_title: Humana has been an interesting experience, though I'm not sure I'd recommend it
pros:
- Lots of emphasis on innovation and the consumer experience, which seems rare for the industry.
- Opportunity to work with a company trying to improve the country's healthcare.
- Benefits are pretty good (Health insurance is subsidized, 401k match is generous, bonuses aren't bad).
cons:
- Too often, decisions are driven by cultural "optics" rather than data.
- I had never encountered the phrase "permission space" before I started at Humana and now I hear it all the time.  I don't feel empowered to do much.
- This is definitely not a fast moving culture or company.

review_title: Good People, Terrible Benefits, Aetna CEO will be improvement
job_title: Senior Actuarial Analyst in Louisville, KY
pros:
Pay is good and exam raises are considered outside of annual raises, so that's definitely a plus
People are a lot of fun and they do try to make the workplace enjoyable and encourage walking breaks
cons: Health Benefits are horrific -- unless you're a 20 something with no spouse/kids and no medications of anykind -- then it's great b/c premium can be less than $10/paycheck and deductibles in excess of $5000

pros: I am able to work from home and flex my time as needed. They have wonderful medical and personal benefits with a competitive salary.
cons: They do focus on numbers a lot which can be stressful and take away from the nursing portion of the job. You have two weeks of training away from home.

review_title: Field Care Manager/ In Home Care Manager
pros: If this were two years ago I could give a whole lot of Pros. However until Humana finishes this downward spiral/ transition  its going through there are no Pros
cons: Humana is downsizing. They are laying off a lot of employees. This position used to be the best. Now they want to put tracking devices on your phone. Cut your schedule in half. They are actually moving salaried employees to hourly pay WOW. I would say that's better than being laid off. But at least if you're laid off you get a severance package.

pros:
Friendly, hard-working co-workers
Some good leaders
cons:
Terrible health insurance -- they should be ashamed of themselves!

They do not value their people -- they treat them as commodities. Right Source is on its way to becoming another Express Scripts. If you're considering working for this company, check out the Express Scripts reviews to see what the future for you will be like.

Got very tired of the General Manager gushing about how well we're doing when many of us have not seen a raise for years. They just give a lot of lip service about "engagement" and "retention," but in the end, don't really care.

I was a good employee. I did good work for this company. I was treated like dirt and set up to fail. I think the health care industry is nothing but a racket, and I'm glad I'm out of it! I got tired of wasting my life and finally left. DON'T WORK HERE!

review_title: Pivot, engage,  circle back, dial in, log off.
pros: Decent pay for what ammounts to being a glorified paper pusher.  If you are lucky enough to get a hot market, money is nice,  when they can pay you properly.  I love the people I work with. Never a dull moment fighting with silos of beuracracy.
cons: Upper management has no clue what the current job requires.  They are out of touch on how anything beyond a golf swing really works. Internal departments have their own agendas and work on different and varied systems. No shades of gray. Training is sub standard, prepackaged, and shows no understanding of the roles they support. New systems, programs and marketing rarely take any real input from those who support and rely on them.

review_title: Convenience of working from home, but role is not as described.
pros: They care about the member and not just "checking the boxes". Working from home is a huge plus. There is definitely a sense that you are helping people manage their health at home. Benefits are decent. Technology is up to date.
cons: Unclear and sometimes unrealistic expectations. Changes are way too frequent- direction can change more than once a day for any given process which is frustrating. Direction not always consistent. Role is not as described during interview/hiring process (AT ALL).

review_title: Formerly one of the best places to work in the Louisville Area. Lately human capital is easily cut
pros: Solid benefits and strong Work/Life Balance culture. Specifically in the Medicare and Medicaid spaces, they have a strong desire to provide a customer well-being focused product/service.
cons: Lately, Humana has cut huge (2,500 locally) numbers of staff to reduce administrative costs. This in spite of record setting stock performance/profitability for the last two years. The loss of the merger offer to Aetna has driven the focus toward earnings per share rather than market growth, further complicated by policy changes regarding ACA repayment.

review_title: Office politics are hamstringing a company that has great potential.
pros: There is an abundance of opportunity within Humana.  If you are in Louisville (HQ), you effectively move up the corporate ladder and salary scale.  Humana is a company that realizes that it needs to evolve to survive in the changing environment.
cons: Communication within and between departments is poor.  Humana is a world of silos with small bastions of power built around managers who protect their worlds with intense fervor.  Problem being that these power structures are not built around people who are competent or effective managers of others.

pros: The company offers a variety of options to help you acquire and/or maintain a healthy lifestyle.  The work isn't very difficult.  And, they can be flexible with time off requests.
cons: The work is quite tedious, however.  If you are someone who prefers a more active/dynamic working environment, this probably isn't the job for you.  It can be difficult to move up, since merit and experience do not play a very significant role in most hiring managers' decisions.

pros: I have worked  for 6 years now, and all 6 have been nothing short of rewarding. From the time I started all the way through present time, it has given me the tools to be successful and rewarded my hard work with the recognition and promotions befit of it.
cons: The cons are limited do to each individuals ideas of importance. For some, work/life balance may be an issue. For others this is not the case. A lot of the perceived cons stem from the branches ability, or lack there of, to properly organize their day and prioritize what is urgent and important

pros: if hired as an limited term employee(LTE), ther are plenty of opportunities for permanent employment. the people are friendly, and the leaders are reasonable. all over time hours are x1.5.
cons: communication between leaders. since LTEs' tasks can be changed at the whims of the supervisors, it gets a little hectic when you have 4. during peak season, if you are in the G&A dep, you will be expected to work up 4 hours over time eveeryday, and even a 6th day if they need you.

review_title: Company that seems to care and invest in it's employees, however, is very clique-ish and hard to move up.
pros: Good compensation and good but not great benefits. PTO is really good and wellness programs are excellent. Company does a really good job at the corporate level.
cons: Medicare segment is stagnate from a growth perspective so it makes it difficult to advance. Again, very clique-ish at the local level which can make it even more difficult. Mid level management is all about watching out for themselves.

pros: You get paid a lot of money and the benefits are wonderful. They allow flex hours and work from home, and if you can keep your head down, you will be golden.
cons: The middle management is the biggest problem in this company. The corporation preaches engagement and work-life  balance, but the reality is that you will be working a lot o f hours. if you have to take FMLA or maternity leave, it is a hit to your career. If you are creative and want to try new things, you will be seen as a problem child. Just go in, do the bare minimum, collect your paycheck, and go home. Anything else will hurt you.

review_title: Middle management needs to learn to be true leaders and not people herders.
pros: The culture at a corporate level is amazing.
cons: Middle management level is horribly out of touch with the general  associate population, the vision of the company and not looking out for the values of the company.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: WFH opportunities and great employee benefits.  Exercise and well-being were greatly emphasized.
cons: If you are not white or Indian, most likely you will not fit comfortably into this environment.  This is a good ole boy network!

review_title: They lie during the interview to make you want to be here
job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: The pay and insurance day one
cons: The insurance is horrible.... 2400.00 deductible. Plus they barely cover anything. The hours are loooonnng. They mandate overtime.... Sometimes the entire month. They offer PTO but you never use it. No sick time. If you are sick you better be here or you will loose your job. Right hand definitely doesn't know what the left hand is doing. Poor management there is no way that you can get a day off without being hospitalized. Seriously. The opportunity for advancement is slim.... To be honest you have to know somebody.

pros: the ability to work from home full time or part and able to flex your schedule most times when needed.
cons: not transparent of major changes that affect everyone such pending merger with Aetna. they get rid of the wrong people and keep the bad seeds that are willing to kiss up to them no matter what. micro-managed for unnecessary things makes it a drag to work there as of lately. no accountability to upper management for the same circumstances they reprimand other employees about.

review_title: Make sure you know exactly what you're getting into...
pros: Humana is generally staffed by intelligent, well-educated, ambitious people.
cons: Since there are so few other options for employment in Louisville, Humana tends to under-deliver on the benefit and development fronts.  In fact, human resources issues and insults to the workforce abound under a dictatorial HR chief.  Also, it is widely known within that to get a decent raise one needs to move around the company a lot - good way to develop political skills, but a poor way of developing functional skills, I'd say.

pros:
smart, dedicated co-workers
focus on well being and health
cons:
politics, looks and favoritism play heavily in promotions
low raises unless you get MIP or other incentives
not the best starting pay
silos

review_title: I've never worked for a company that has valued my experience, health, family and personal goals the Humana does.
job_title: Personal Health Coach in Cincinnati, OH
pros: It's not just a place to work, it's a support system. The pay is above what most companies offer. Four weeks of paid time off and 8 hours paid volunteer time. Ever expanding company filled with opportunity.
cons: It's not the easiest to stand out, especially with the amount of hiring, strong performance and networking is a must.

review_title: Managers that have no business being managers
pros: Company benefits are really nice.  Lots of locations for employment .  Associate to Associate contact was great including help and follow through.
cons: Very ignorant, un-trained managers.  Hard work does not matter.  Worked out side of work hours and not paid.  Not amenable for transfers, approvals for such transfers have to be approved by Director.  Internal management intimate relationships.  Promotions to individuals that are on probationary action and still allowed promotion by supervisor just to move them from the current managers responsibility.  Dictators in management.  Micro management huge problem.  It is about who you know in the company.

pros: Benefits are good, work at home options are available to some but at a cost, on site clinic and pharmacy at the waterside building
cons:
Recent layoffs in an effort to find cheaper workforce, recently eliminated close to 10% of employee workforce at the height of their financial success. If you’re able to work under someone intelligent it’s a great place to work but more often than not leaders are power hungry and unprofessional. 
Bad management 
Money hungry company
Old buildings 
When you work at home you’re often forgotten about when it comes to promotions or performance reviews

review_title: Pretty good place to work for screening pharmacists
pros:
- Can work from home
- Pay starts a bit low but you get raises every year so over time you can make more than hospital or retail
- Flexibility with schedule, pretty easy to get days off and so forth
- Good benefits
- As long as you hit your rates no one bugs you, there is no manager over your shoulder or patients to deal with
- Can do enjoyable things while working to help pass time like listen to music, podcasts, etc
- Paid time off available right from the start
- New incentive plan so you can get bonuses
cons:
- The system is absolute garbage.  Came from Fry's which had a good system and it's almost shocking that a system so convoluted can even function.  You need all sorts of programs open to do your job and the Epost system has all sorts of errors that you have to work around and they rarely fix anything.
-  Mandatory OT and this is getting worse.  When I started you signed a contract saying you accept mandatory OT will be a thing but they said over and over would only be in January and February.  Well lately it's been happening almost year round and it ranges from 3-5 hours per week usually.  They seem to be ok keeping the department understaffed which also makes it hard to be able to get time off and vacation. 
-  Some managers are better than others.  There are a lot of teams in the department under what's known as an FLL boss.  Most of them are pretty cool but if you get one that sucks not fun.
-  High rate requirements.  If you can work fast this isn't an issue, but if not you are screwed at a job like this.

pros: ?....a steady paycheck?  It seems as if employees like to work for Humana, because they stay there for a long time. However I think those are the employees that are just there to collect a paycheck.
cons: Management doesn't allow for growth.  I think it may be in part because of job insecurity.  In addition employees beneath the management level are not given bonuses based on performance  and cost savings.   Only management reeps the benefits of bonuses.  I think that sends a message to employees that their efforts are not as valued as management.

pros: Corporate tower is beautiful.  People enjoy what they do (for the most part).  The innovation center is an awesome place to work.  The company is open to trying new things.  It's good times to work for Humana since the company is obviously making money.
cons: People view the company as a "health insurance" company.  We offer so much more than that.  Company is too large.  Nobody knows all that is going on.  Humana should work towards a company wide blog / wiki to allow for associates from other departments to learn about what departments like CGO are doing.  Often times there is a lot of duplication of work.

pros: Work at home opportunity was wonderful - it was my first venture into WAH and I would highly recommend this to anyone with a good work ethic.  Everything needed to WAH was provided by the company.
cons: Inadequate training, frequent leadership changes and frequent process changes made for a lot of frustration.  Worse yet, just as I started, one of the leadership team announced their resignation and had already totally checked out.  A significant period of time passed before someone else came on board and this person was also totally new to the company and was not well trained.

pros: Excellent training, they advertise & there are several leads to distribute, benefits were okay & had matching 401K. You work from your home & travel to the leads. They do pay mileage & I had an expense account.
cons: On a state level it is tight knit. If they covet your leads/book of business/etc., they will black ball you in order to get them. Some agents who have been there for an extended period of time were terminated on something trivial in order to not have to pay them renewals.

pros: Co-workers, great direct boss, most all of the workforce is virtual/work at home
cons: Senior Leadership guidance and direction; unrealistic work deadlines/expectations

review_title: Very political, but overall a good place to work.
pros:
Many opportunities across the company to gain experience
One of the largest employers in town (limited alternatives)
There are some very bright people working at Humana - you can learn a lot from them
cons:
Hires too many consultants to tell management what our internal employees have already said
Career growth is a free-for-all, no defined structure
If you want a decent raise you will need to leave the company
Industry is under constant attack
Very political - almost to the point of paralysis
Many employees are disengaged due to uncertainty, layoffs, and overwhelming politics

review_title: Depends on who you work for
pros: Benefits, salary, HumanaVitality, coworkers, agile work opportunities, excellent 401k match
cons: leadership - Humana is very hierarchical and your leader as far as 3 levels up can have a huge impact on your day-to-day work.  Who you report to greatly determines your overall experience at Humana.  Some co-workers have amazing bosses and love coming to work.  Mine, on the other hand have made my life miserable at times.  My advice: do a lot of research as to who you will be reporting to and what they are like to work for.

review_title: Overall good good company to work for.  HR is terribly slow though
pros: Pay is decent for the area.  Management is good.  Office culture is fun if you are not on phones.  Lots of PTO, if you aren't on calls.  Lots of potential for movement within the company.  401k match is awesome.
cons: If you are on calls getting any sort of time off is hard.  When applying for new jobs within the company HR is terribly slow.  Almost to the point that it is insulting.  For being an insurance company you would think the benefits would be great...not so much.  All options are High Deductible Health Plans.

review_title: Great company training, but poor processes and ownership of duties
pros: The pay is great!  The people you work with make it worth while!  Your contribution and suggestions are taken seriously, but you seldom have the opportunity to act on any of the suggestions.
cons: After the restructuring, no one knew what their job encompasses and did not receive the proper training to even do their new job.  It was the most frustrating mess you could imagine!

pros: Great place to work, big enough to forge your own path.  Competitive pay in a city that can offer stability.
cons: While big enough to make your own career, some units of the company fall into organizational issues that can cause extra work and stress to be shifted to associates who are proactive and willing to step up.  This is great for short-term solutions, bad for long term health and well-being; which can cause turnover.

job_title: Medicare Sales Representative in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Incredible 5 Star training for 3 weeks in Louisville, KY. , Good health insurance and 401k matching program.
cons: Weak, unqualified management of all white men. My manager hid from us, missing from our office for weeks at a time. Getting paid $250,000.00 annually, his only job was keeping his job. Never wanted to risk using new ideas to increase sales. Just wanted to fly under the radar. Was supposed to take new hires and “show us the ropes” but never took us out once. Took the men in office out for drinks, lunches and pro football and baseball games but women were never included. Fired me while I was on FMLA. And yes, they can do whatever they want.

pros: Absolutely none. Anything you can get here, you can actually get with any other employer. They are actually the only employer that would discontinue your health insurance on the same day as your last day at work even after they cut the insurance premium from your last paycheck.
cons: Lack of of communication and carelessness of management. Not very good pay. Impossible to grow inside. Not helping you improve or move forward in your career. Managers are biased and disorganized. The company policy is designed to put everything regarding your future in your (front line leader’s) hand. It seems most of the time that you are not working for a corporate but for one person called the ( front line leader). Zero leadership and 100% bossiness. No clear instructions or enough training. Very stressful to work there. It’s not worth it.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: Work at home position. Hours were pretty much the same Monday thru Friday. No holidays. No weekends.
cons: Constantly changing the amount of calls that had to be made daily. You were "dinged" all the time and your overall "report card" scores would go down when members would not answer and/or refused to participate in the program. Always felt like I was a salesperson instead of a nurse. Extremely difficult to convince members that you could benefit them from just speaking to a nurse.

review_title: Humana is a good company with many career paths
pros: Humana provides a lot of room for career growth in a variety of different areas.  It is also a complex and ever-changing environment that affords new challenges from day-to-day.
cons: Working for a large company can mean that things move slowly.  This can be frustrating if you see a need for change.

pros:
Work from home option for many positions. 
Onsite Fitness Center.
cons: Production rates are always increasing, never good enough. Raise you right out the door if you can't keep up. Must adhere to time keeping software or you'll receive a "coaching", IM chat time is watched like a hawk, too many emails with little " approved" time to read them, leadership teams are clueless, and if you want to move up in the company, you better suck up to the right people because skills do not matter. PTO is a benefit you're lucky to use if they let you and paid holidays are always questionable if you'll be required to work on them. Overtime during December through February is ridiculous: kiss your life and family goodbye... So much for "well-being".

pros: Good pay and great co workers. Very diverse place to work. Good training on new implementations
cons: Management will stunt your growth if you are not friends with them or their friends dont like you. Upper management will always see eye to eye with your direct manager even when they clearly are in the wrong

review_title: My experience at a Humana owned clinic
pros: Benefits, but not for newbies in the clinical setting. They lowered the new hires benefits package. Lots of support for well being and health.
cons: I work for a subsidiary of Humana. No room to grow, stuck in the same position for five years and accomplished tons of stuff, but others received credit.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in West Chester, OH
pros: The vacation time is generous.  Sick time and vacation time is rolled together for a total of 4 weeks paid time off per year.
cons:
Poor quality insurance.  
No bonuses. 
Small wage increases usually around 2‰.  
No growth potential inside the company.  Regardless of the position you may move up to,  they will fight giving you more than a 5% increase. 
Company tries to control your life outside of work.

review_title: Personal Health Coach PHC, work at home
pros: Work from home is the only pro
cons: They make it sound very flexible and that you will have free time for education, "well-being time" and 15 minutes breaks.  But once you get past probation, all bets off.  You can't meet metrics and have any well-being time and rarely get to take breaks if you want to make your metrics. Management only cares about ROI (return on investment) and it's shareholders. Upper management  has recently sold all the stock shares they were legally allowed to sell. There is a huge turnover of executives "retiring" only to go to other companies.  The Aetna merger didn't happen and they over-staffed so layoffs are still coming. They do not care about the staff that make direct contact with members. You are just a lightbulb to be screwed in, burnt out, removed and replaced again.

review_title: Get what you need before you come through the door.  Once you are in, it is hard to move up.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: Some of the sections are GREAT places to work.  Excellent relationships with your coworkers and your boss.  Humana is pretty much the big dog in Louisville and it seems like everyone wants to work here.  Humana does try to do things right, but sometimes they might not be the right things.  Can be committed to change, just have a hard time following through, etc.  Pay can be great, if you can get it.
cons:
Seniority is definitely favored over competence.  Too many managers have been here too long and just are not up to the task of leading a Fortune 100 company.  What aggravates the problem is that many of the directors and VP’s are unable or unwilling to move or remove their ineffectual leadership.  VERY little training given to new managers and again, most are out of their league (Peter Principle).  They are on their own once they get promoted and as such most do not have the tools, much less actual experience to help them.  

There is a big divide between the Manager-class (who can get yearly bonuses) and the associates (who don’t).  There is no standard of performance across the roles.  Your promotion potential is more dependant upon the interest and qualities of your manager, than your own capabilities/education/competence/experience, etc.  Some sections promote often and early and others only once in a blue moon.

pros: The pay is good, the benefits do cost a little more and you do have high deductibles but at least we have something, with so many people unemployed
cons: Senior Management needs classes on anger management and how to actually treat people It has gotten better in the years I have been there but I trully believe that they are only nice because it is now expected of them, but not really how they want to treat us.

review_title: My Coworkers were fantastic, and Humana shows great concern for their employees during times of crisis
job_title: Nurse Care Manager in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Work from Home, a great program for getting in shape or maintaining your health (Vitality), pays up to 6.5% above what the employee contributes to their 401K
cons: Senior Leadership is only focused on quantity not quality although they claim quality is of utmost importance. They also pride themselves on being military friendly but do not make allowances for military related disabilities. (and yes, I know a couple of former employees who have filed ethics complaints)

review_title: With such a large company, easy to get lost in the shuffle, tough to get anything done.
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits and strong wellness incentives. My organization within the company is centered around sales, so earning potential is virtually unlimited.
cons: During peak selling seasons, it's tough to achieve work life balance. As much as Humana advocates this as part of well being, they also want you to work 60 hours a week.

review_title: Great place to work with, Senior Leadership could use some direction
pros:
Great benefits
Great work environment 
Great values 
Very generous with their compensation 
Very eager to grow talent
cons:
While they are eager to grow talent, they lack in their ability to understand you can only compensate them as their "title" for so long before you actually need to promote them.

Senior Leadership in some markets have an extremely high turnover due to lack of noticing anything other than their personal bottom line.

review_title: If I could give less than 1 star, I would.
job_title: Clinical Nurse Advisor in Green Bay, WI
pros: Work from home, no weekends.  Good pay.
cons: It's like management makes up the rules as they go along. The latest is taking away our flex time option (even for people who have been doing it for years), without being able to give us a valid reason or show us a policy with the changes. Management is NOT honest and transparent although they seem to pride themselves on thinking they are. Employees are too scared to speak up, because those that "rock the boat" either get fired or have their lives made into such a living hell that they quit.  Right now everyone is afraid of losing their jobs with the upcoming Aetna merger.....and so much work is being shipped overseas.....we are all being kept in the dark and it's terrifying.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Memphis, TN
pros: You get to Work from home. That's the only one I could think of honestly. I would say flexibility, but really not as flexible as you would think once the micromanagement is factored in.
cons:
They give you so much work to do that you end up working all day and all night!
Metrics out the whazoo- no mater how hard you work you won't be able to meet their expectations
Micromanaged- you have to answer the phone in 3 rings, they log your keystrokes, record your calls, its like a reality show!
35K a year??? For an RN ??? Out of their minds!

pros: Great pay, Good amount of paid time off, Nice co-workers, clean offices, safe offices to work in, Lots of jobs to apply for.
