pros: Company is focused on well-being and serving their membership.  Salaries are competitive or slightly higher than the industry average.
cons: While the company is focused on well-being, work/life balance for its associates is challenging.  The employer contribution for health benefit coverage could be better.  While salaries might be slightly higher than the industry average, associates have a greater out-of-pocket responsibility for their healthcare expenses.

job_title: Personal Health Coach in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Great work environment, supervisors are really supportive and helpful. Work from home, overall easy job. Lots if support and great employees. The compamy as a whole has great programs. They encourage individuals personal growth. I simply LOVE my job!!
cons: Insurance benefits aren't the best, but still pretty good. They are now merging with Aetna, so that could possibly mean serious changes down the road

pros: The company is ideal for associates looking to build their experience fresh out of college, or for those interested in changing career tracks in a new industry. The opportunities to develop skills in leadership, professional development, and to gain understanding of the healthcare industry are readily available in a variety of roles. There is a high level of safety and autonomy for associates, though those in front-line (customer service, service center etc.) roles, will find fewer opportunities for growth. The pay scale average for roles is higher than for comparable companies, though salaried associates will find they're expected to earn it through long hours. The focus on well-being and work/life balance is a positive one, though not always realized in practice (especially not in frontline, service center or individual contribution roles). Some roles have agile work - meaning, work from home and/or flexibility. Health care benefit cost is moderate, and the monthly coverage is middle-grade. Diversity in teams is a huge plus, and the variance of skill-sets for associates is a unique factor for this company.
cons: Depending upon the area of the business (non-management, service center) and the time of year (such as Open Enrollment), project work for salaried associates and/or volume for service center associates can be extremely high. It was common for associates to work 60-70, even some 80+ hour work weeks when large scale projects were nearing implementation. Associates may have to work mandatory overtime, including holidays. There are some very skilled and caring leaders at the company, though there are also leaders who focus on the metrics, and any focus on work/life balance completely disappears. Roles in education and training may be better suited for singles willing to travel and work extremely long hours, especially outside the office (evenings/weekends).

pros: The benefits are great.  They provider opportunites to be involved with the community and to try to obtain a healthier lifestyle.
cons: The health insurance could be better with respect to what the company actually pays.  It doesn't pay to be healthy since you most likely will never reach your deductible and as such the company doesn't pay.  The most you get are discounts but not much.

pros: Competitive salary. Ability to work from home. Great incentives from company. Friendly co-workers. That's all I have to say about the company.
cons: HR department has no idea how to handle complaints against upper management. Management sits around all day and talk about employees. Very unprofessional environment. Very catty woman in management roles. They would get upset if you do not want to be a member of their click and try to reprimand you by making up an excuse to fire you.

pros: option to work from home, health an wellness incentives
cons: lay off are always around the corner so job security is always a concern, upper management does not always follow through or think things through before making changes in program an work duties are changing every month prematurely every time someone has a bright idea with out proper planning. Culture of biting off more then they can handle. They promise opportunity to grow within out of 3 years no one on my team earn a promotion within the company.

pros: Can make decent money if you work hard and work overtime.  Lots of good people there from all ends of the spectrum.  Decent work environment.  During the slow season there is plenty of availibility for time off.
cons: Management is all over the place.  During the busy season they lay off of you but the slow season they are breathing down your neck.  Rules are constantly changing.

pros: Good people and friends. Facilities are nice.
cons: Benefits are sub-par and pay equity is questionable.  Company is always up for sale making it a stressful environment to work in not knowing if job stability exists.  HR has a long way to go to get to be a world class organization.  Company changes are so quick that getting daily work done is extremely difficult.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Daytona Beach, FL
pros: Geriatric patients are usually friendly and caring.
cons: Too much workload, very stressful environment, high turnover rate, very corporate and all about how many patients they can see vs quality care.

pros:
Some work schedule flexibility
Decent overall benefits
Some opportunity to amass new professional skills
cons:
Unprofessional attitudes from high-level managers
Lack of communication from above
Too much outsourcing
Pay feels below average
Health care options for employees of a health insurance company are so limited it almost feels like a joke
Not enough time spent on true employee development

pros: The company puts a lot of money and time into attracting the best talent.    They offer educational seminars and internships to students from top colleges.
cons: Performance reviews and advancement are based on subjective criteria.   HR provides no support when employees encounter unethical issues with management.

job_title: WFM Front Line Leader in Louisville, KY
pros: Cares a lot about well being, very friendly environment to work in. Not your typical cut throat business model.
cons: Very VERY political company, old school business practices still used today even though they are out of date. As with any big company, vision and communication are for the woo, application of vision doesn't always play out.

pros: There are a few work from home opportunities. But then they expect longer hours
cons: No raises. Benefits cut. The most expensive health insurance in the industry with the poorest benefits and highest deductibles.  They hire nonpar under educated people without proper business or area expertise and their IT is the worst. None of the computer systems work. So much down time for everyone. Then changes every week to processes no one can keep up. There has been a mass exodus. Does not advance from within

pros: The company provides a ton of flexibility to employees. If work / life balance is important, Humana will usually accommodate your needs.
cons:
Experiences can be quite different depending on the area you work in. It's a big company and not everyone I know has had the same experience. There is a tendency to see front line employees as morons which is not the case.

Like any big company, politics is critical to success. Who you know is more important than what you know.

review_title: Humana has grown larger and quality of care and of communication needed for a good work environment has suffered.
pros:
Larger company can offer room for growth.

Some good staff to work with, learn from and get to know.
cons:
They are so big that communication within the company becomes difficult.  

The structure is set too big across the country. This leads to too much red tape, which waste time and to decisions being made by higher ups who do not fully understand all segments.  That then leads to poor decision making. 

Benefits cost employees more than average in other health plans.

The different health plans/companies acquired would be managed better if they were managed separately. They reassign acquired company functions to existing staff, who are unfamiliar with the plans. Naturally the staff is unable to produce 5 star work, because they are unprepared and overloaded with work.  This is unfair to the employees and unfair to consumers.  Everyone suffers.

They only offer their own "Humana" health insurance to their employees, which is costly compared to other good commercial plans in the healthcare market.  And, if you opt out, they force you to pay a penalty.  Society would think that a health plan would be more considerate in this benefit, most of all. 

Humana is a private plan, so making a profit is priority, not the employee or the consumer.

pros: Salary is good and the work environment and the people are great. Humana has a strong focus on well-being and promotes the wellness of employees with great programs, on site gyms, healthy foods.
cons: With a big company and many processes, sometimes the red tape gets in the way of addressing issues quickly. Luckily the people truly care, it just takes awhile to get things done.

pros: Great 401K. The salary is high for Louisville. The company is progressing in terms of formality - no longer have to wear a tie to work, work at home is more flexible, employee well-being is finally important. PTO is solid. Belive it or not, really interesting industry.
cons: As expected at a large company that deals with the government for the majority of its revenue, there is considerable bureaucracy. There is also a lot of overlap - multiple teams working on the same thing. Silos among business units are an issue as well.

review_title: Customer Care Leadership needs a facelift
job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Chandler, AZ
pros: Surrounding yourself with the right people, on the job training outside the classroom and perks for being healthy is awesome working here. Recognition helps employees feel confident.
cons: Leadership can improve with employee engagement. Better pay structure for workers who are dedicated. Value your top performers by increasing pay instead of giving blanket statements of when a pay raise may become available.

job_title: Personal Health Coach in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Overall good people that work there with a genuine desire to help its members.
cons: Corporate/ Executive level management is many times not in touch with the employees providing direct services. This often times results in subjective Corporate decisions that ultimately results in employees and members seeing a form of care that often is driven by reports and data collection opposed to services rendered or needed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: There is opportunity to grow, most of the benefits a pretty good, there is a lot opportunity to learn new things.
cons: The health insurance is very expensive. If you have a bad manager you are out of luck, but they change often so there is always hope a new person will take over.

job_title: Medical Coder in Green Bay, WI
pros: 8 hours of paid volunteer time, ability to work at home.
cons: Where do I even begin? Micromanagement, under constant threat of losing our jobs,  expecting us to do the job of 6 people and then being berated for not being able to keep up with everything. Quantity over quality mentality.  No pension plan, expensive insurance coverage that the majority of employees cannot even afford. Difficulty getting time off work unless you are a "favorite".  I don't have enough room to say how horrible this company has become.

pros: Humana has a cafeteria and gym in the building (the Hillsborough location). They have a decent bonus program if you can meet certain metrics.
cons: The managers are unprofessional,  it's about who you know not what you know. If you're part of the in crowd you're okay but if certain managers don't like you, you're going to have a hard time. Most of the managers look unhappy and the phone reps too.  They have several areas this review is for medicare/medicaid phones and H1036.

pros: Humana has been a great place to work.  Competitive salary and excellent benefits.  Unfortunately recent restructuring has resulted in numerous lay offs.  Finding a new position internally has been more difficult than initial hiring. This is an area in which Humana could improve.  They appear to not offer internal employees first options on available positions.  They lose excellent employees because of this
cons: Recent lay offs and difficulty finding internal positions when part of reduction in force

pros: Work at home, benefits, work/life balance
cons:
There really is no room for advancement.  Major layoffs - i think they are eliminating our department, lack of communication, work is boring, things get dumped on CHE's and numbers are okay to hit, but doesn't give much time for us to grow as individuals by taking extra courses, shadow other departments, etc.  

If you are not laid off you will likely be stuck in the role you are in for years.

review_title: Good at first, but in constant fear of RIF which eventually happened.
pros: Work life balance, PTO, associate incentive plan, flexible scheduling.
cons: Micromanagement, very little room to move up in the Humana at Home division. Will not be surprised if HAH is gone within the year. Care used to be wonderful and would have happily referred friends or family to Humana. Not any more.

pros: Hourly pay was great, as well as commission. You get to pick your own schedule after the standard 9-5 training is completed. They’ll cover the cost of your licensing, if you aren’t already licensed, during training. Amazing benefits that start from day 1. Pay and benefits are all that I miss from this company.
cons:
Dress code — why is there a “business”-level dress code? No customers are allowed in the building, no one sees you. Management clearly played favorites with this rule.

Training — training was all over the place. No consistent trainers. One manager trains you for a few days, then another, another, another, etc. The training classes themselves are reminiscent of a high school classroom. The people they then pair you with after training is over are usually quite awful. For the most part, they’re unwilling to help you, other than berating you for not doing the job as well as them, or they’re bitter that they were asked to help someone and now they themselves are losing sales, so they’re not exactly helpful.

Management — while there were a couple of truly, honestly great managers that I enjoyed working with and being around...most were just awful people. You can tell they were miserable and stretched thin, but it’s not an excuse to berate others or literally yell and insult people. Never a good way to set an example. 

Technology — computer systems consistently down and not working. Can’t make money if phones and/or computers aren’t working. Still expected to somehow make the company money, though.

Overall, the mental stress isn’t worth the pay.

job_title: Dms Sales Agent in Hong Kong
pros: Easy work but will take a lot of calls ....
cons: You will take a lot of calls as CS Dept does not know what they are doing....low pay position and many times they are outsourced from other countries. ... Right Hand DOES NOT KNOW What The Left Hand Is Doing Scenario. ...

review_title: The guys at the top mean well - but, wow.... it gets lost (badly) down in the ranks
job_title: Project Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: vacation time is generous; lots of programs to improve health; C level leadership appears to try hard to make it a good place.
cons: (this may depend on location)... lower/middle management gets waaaay to much into your personal life (breaking the law, actually).  This creates a catty, nasty, unprofessional environment with a lot of back-biting.  Unbelievably - the health insurance is the worst I've seen in 30 years of various employers.

review_title: Life is what you make it.
pros: The culture has so much potential.  Healthy living and personal wellness is strongly emphasized.  I love the learning resources available.
cons: It is all about who you know.  Introvert?  Get ready to step out of your comfort zone and sometimes deal with confrontation.

job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Cincinnati, OH
pros: The pay was very good, more than competitive and certainly beat Wellpoint.  The people were great and they took the time to train people well.  I also had a positive opinion of management.
cons: The user interface was tedious and made it difficult to multitask.  I also found it rather difficult to get time off when I needed it.

pros: I am a people person and love helping others. At Humana that is what we do, provide perfect service to our members.
cons: Within any company there will be something that will not set well with others. The one thing that I feel can be improved here at Humana is that they need to take a closer look at the talent that they have within the company.

job_title: Cash Posting Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: fair compensation. work hours somewhat flexible, depending what area you work. health and wellness incentives.are standard. Ability to work virtually.
cons: once hired, don't expect  to move within the organization, unless you happen to get lucky to have a manager, or director who is of like mind.. Humana is top heavy in management. Rarely have a pulse on associates daily work. You best prepare yourself to be an exceptional associate, as well as belong to the right clique in order to get ahead in your career.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Deerfield Beach, FL
pros: Pay rate was equivalent to what the base pay up north is. which is 15 an hour up north. I respected and appreciated that start off pay with access to uncapped OT hours and many more opportunities. hour for lunch.
cons: you start off at night shift. phone calls can be stressful when all managers are on deck helping others. and you must wait for them. which means so does the customer.

review_title: Wouldn't do it again! RUN AWAY!
job_title: Medicare Enrollment Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Great benefits

Pay was "okay"

They buy you a bunch of licenses
cons:
The management/supervisors here are horrible. Squabbling children.  You have to keep your mouth shut and kiss butt here. It's like walking on egg shells.

If you are under 50 years old, DO NOT WORK HERE. This place is a breeding ground for old people who complain and cry all day.

review_title: Great company if you have a good manager
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: 3 weeks of training in Kentucky. They promise you the world.
cons: The company gives management all of the control. When you have a crazy, spiteful, racist, evil manager you’re career is stunted. There is no way around it. I’ve seen this manager in particular, prey on people, and ruin their career. Plus the work is grueling! With no actual office, they have you in the streets begging for customers. The network is terrible not many doctors participative.

review_title: Great place to grow and pursue new challenges
pros: There is a commitment by management to encourage and facilitate growth. During my time there I met regularly with my manager to discuss my current challenges, to seek guidance, as well as my career objectives, to  develop a strategy to get me there. The company offers lots of career paths and seems dedicated to  promoting from within.
cons: The healthcare industry as a whole is highly regulated, especially Medicare, which is  Humana's specialty. So sometimes progress seems slow on certain projects, as Legal painstakingly reviews everything.

review_title: Very impressed!  They care about employee engagement, well being, etc.!   WOW!
pros: Great company.   They actually care about their associates and about their well being.  It's a "wellness" company and they really take it seriously.  They want their associates to have a healthy work/life balance. They do not micro-manage.  They give you the freedom to do your job.  They are selective when hiring, to give perfect customer service.  Opportunities for advancement.   LOVE THEM!
cons: Some people work at home, which I have been told is a little lonely.

pros: Strong sales and messaging at times ( SmartSuite).   Showed abilities around Innovation.
cons: Never decided what they wanted to be, tried a lot and not much took off.  Now it's best option is Medicare and everything else is second tier in the marketplace at best.   Medicare of course the clear exception.

pros: Good people to work with, cheap medical insurance, 23 days PTO, feel leadership cares about you.
cons: Long hours and weekend work, many work from home so no face to face time in building relationships, many new items to track on top of current work due to merger and restructure.

job_title: Applications Engineer Intern in Louisville, KY
pros: Humana is a good company that offers you a lot of opportunities to move around within the company based one what you want to do. This is a great place to intern while in college  as a freshman or sophomore to get your first real world experience.
cons: Being a large company in the healthcare industry things move very slow. If you want to be on the cutting edge of technology or to truly challenge yourself as an computer engineer then Humana will fall short in keeping your fulfilled.

job_title: Personal Health Coach in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Good salary for the FL region
cons: Humana went down some time ago. It was a stress free environment then they hired young, vibrant, type A personalities who thought more could be done, to the point of scaring the workers. Overworked the ones doing the job and was callous about it.

review_title: Humana, a big stable job, but super restrictive security/IT.
pros: Humana was big, stable, and slow.  That could be good or bad depending on your perspective.  But they had a lot of money unlike all of the SMB's I've worked for.
cons: Super restrictive IT Security.  They did not care at all that you could not do your job, as long as IT was locked down.

job_title: Consultative Pharmacy Technician in Glendale, AZ
pros: Okay pay, amazing co-workers, amazing leadership
cons: Terrible work life balance, pay could be better for the amount of OT and workload that is put on the techs.

review_title: Good pay and benefits but only limited career advancement.
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Employees are friendly, competent, and helpful.
cons: Humana has a history of hiring staff to create high-profit years and then dramatically cutting staff when there is concern, but not evidence, of coming lean years.  Humana also has a history of heavy use of offshore resources.  Extremely bottom-line oriented versus employee oriented.

pros: People are friendly and helpful.  Associates in all offices seemed to always be willing to help.  Downtown Louisville facilities are state of the art.  Lots of corporate discounts.
cons: Associates are not appreciated or recognized all the time.  Front line managers are poor leaders, and like to micromanage.  Poor health care benefits offered to associates.

review_title: Pretty good company to work for
pros: Good work environment along with friendly coworkers. There are lots of job openings at any given time. Supervisors are willing to help you pursue your goals within the company.
cons: It isn't always what you know as much as it is who you know. Lock out periods make it tough to move when you become interested in a position. Poor health benefits for employees considering it's a health insurance company.

pros: Great benefits, great support staff, hours are pretty much your own time as a Marketpoint representative. income is unlimited. Competitive salary, competitive products
cons: Managers are not on the same page at times. If you don't meet the minimum benchmarks you will manage yourself out of the job. Integrity is a huge issue

review_title: Dead end job unless you are an IT manager or an Actuary.
pros: Vacation time is good, there are a few small wellness perks that are good.  The low level workers are nice.
cons: No possibility for advancement unless you are a loud mouthed know it all or major kiss up to anyone that has a heart beat.  Pay is well below the industry standard and the executives are the only ones that reap the profits with huge bonuses and incentives while the lower level employees work every weekend and nights using outdated ridiculous systems and lacking technology.

job_title: MarketPoint Career Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: PCRA 401k, salary + benefits. You own your own franchise and have to manage your time effectively but taught me a lot about being a better sales agent. Company really takes care of their employees.
cons: There were a lot of politics in our office and the management team has a lot of control over your ultimate success or failure long term.

review_title: Steady State -but if you’re looking for a true progressiveHealthCare disrupter this is not the place for you
pros: Overall I think Humana is working to be a innovative progressive company
cons: Not a great place for Millennials- The company is still very traditional in many ways whereas Humana has a culture of promoting experience versus true people leaders, this has become so systemic that it has become hardwired into the culture

pros: Get to work from home.  Some good benefits and flexible schedule.
cons: Poor training, poorly organized. Have been 3 layoffs in the last 9 months.  Constant change in how you are expected to do your job but yet minimal information and instruction is passed along. You pretty much have to learn as you go.

review_title: Great salary great wellness benefits poor management
pros: Great salary. Great wellness benefits. Humana vitality Humana nurse line Humana cares fitness facility with trainers massage employee lounges chef created cafe delicious
cons: Poor management poor follow up to employee issues poor communication when not at management level a lot of pettiness amongst coworkers claim to have internal jobs available but really just give the jobs to their friends and pretend to have interview process odd decision layoffs

review_title: Data science and analytics are growing at Humana, cultural change required to take full advantage of it.
pros: Leadership is driving a positive cultural change at the company.  Company performance in a challenging environment has been very good.  Heavy investment in data science.
cons: Organizational structure needs a major overhaul.  Many departments are so stuck in antiquated thinking and processes.

review_title: I have had wonderful experiences working at Humana. They truly value their employees and their well-being.
pros: Decent salary, nice 401k matching, flexible schedule, wellness programs, $5000 annual tuition reimbursement and access to a college coach who helps you get started going back to school
cons: Management isn't all that approachable and can sometimes micromanage too much. Lack of trust sometimes. The systems are complex and cumbersome to learn.

job_title: Personal Health Coach in Cincinnati, OH
pros: This organization pays well and has good benefits. There a lot of programs for employees, including wellness and discount programs. Many positions, including mine, allow you to work from hime.
cons: This company is going through a lot of changes and it's a bit chaotic. Positions change quickly and training is often not sufficient for transitions. There is a huge emphasis on production numbers and that can be very demanding.

pros: Company offers a ton of plans and commission structure is better than most out there
cons: selling some of their plans in states is tough because they tend to be more expensive. They do not provide sufficient training and a lot of it is learn as you go/self taught.

job_title: Transition Coordinator/Care Coach in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Humana corporate supports its associates for example when we were affected by a hurricane and they offered severals options for assistance in addition to allowing time to recover. Humana also has good incentives for well being.
cons: Lots of leadership changes make it hard to know what is expected as the criteria changes with each leader.  Systems sometimes don’t make sense to those who have to put them into practice.

review_title: Great job with a lot of opportunities.
pros: Ability to strengthen communication and technological skills.  I have had the opportunity to work in 5 different roles in the 5+ years of working at Humana.
cons: It can feel like a political environment at times.  It is important to build relationships with those in leadership positions by showing them that you are competent and accountable.

review_title: Leadership and management bogus. HR is a joke.
pros: Great teams (if your supervisor and/or manager are worth anything) and OK discounts through employe programs.
cons: Complaints against management are brushed under the rug. Intimidation, blackmail and threats are a norm. Thieves and liars promoted because they kiss the right parts of the right people.

pros:
Company is very health conscious and provides a number of incentives for living a healthy lifestyle. 
 A positive member experience is goal of each and every associate within the organization.
cons:
Management is not focused on the development of future leaders with the organization, unless you are an Infusion candidate.
Organization still struggles with territorialism and good ole boy mentality

pros: Great benefits and wellness programs for employees - multiple departments that can lead to different lateral moves.  Lots of opportunities for doing different types of things
cons: Hard to move up, internal politics within the top ranks make it difficult to break in.  Salaries tend to be at market or below with few raises once hired
